DOC.HEAD: Students March Peacefully For Slain Teaneck Youth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6 grafs after 3rd pvs to UPDATE with newspaper report that youth carried BB pistol. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Spath has...
DOC.TEXT: About 200 college students marched through this northern New Jersey community Friday, hoping to defuse tensions that flared following the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager by a white policeman. ``We sympathize with the death of Phillip Pannell,'' said Walter Fields, an official with the Bergen County chapter of the NAACP. ``We don't condone the violence but we do thoroughly understand the anger.'' Pannell, 16, of nearby River Edge was shot and killed Tuesday night by Teaneck police officer Gary Spath, who was responding to an anonymous telephone tip that a teen-ager had drawn a gun on another youth. In another development, The New York Times reported in its Saturday editions that Phillip's companions said he had been handling a BB pistol before officers confronted them. The newspaper reported that several youths, interviewed separately, said that Phillip was fooling around with the BB gun when police approached the group. Pannell put the gun in his coat pocket and took off running just before police intended to frisk him and the others, the youths told the newspaper. It was then that the officer shot, killing Pannell, they said. Police have said they recovered a loaded .22 caliber gun from Pannell. Another youth, however, told the Times that another youngster carried the BB pistol away. Spath has since been suspended with pay and his partner, Wayne Blanco, has been temporarily relieved of his duties, acting Bergen County Prosecutor John Holl said. A grand jury is scheduled to begin hearing testimony on the case on Tuesday. Franklin Wilks, an attorney representing Pannell's mother, Thelma Pannell, held a news conference later Friday to release details of an independent medical examiner's report. Wilks said the report corroborates eyewitnesses who said Pannell had his arms up in the air at the time he was shot in the back. Witnesses said Pannell was running away from police when he was shot. Police said a loaded pistol was found on his body. Wilks said he had not seen a report by the Bergen County medical examiner, which found the boy had been killed by a single shot in the back. A peaceful candlelight vigil Wednesday night in remembrance of the slain youth turned violent as mostly black teen-agers roamed local streets smashing store windows and overturning cars. Much of the damage remained visible Friday. Plywood had replaced what used to be windows in many businesses along Teaneck Road. The students who walked through Teaneck were members of the Union of African Student Organizations, which represents 14 colleges in northern New Jersey. They included blacks, Hispanics and whites. The students set out from the Teaneck campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University, winding through the township and up Teaneck Road to Tryon Park, close to where Phillip was killed. The event did not disrupt traffic and the group had no police escorts. During the three-hour march, participants talked with residents and merchants, Fields said. ``We tell them we're here because we're concerned,'' Fields said. ``What's needed now is healing. We need to come together as a community.'' At Tryon Park, a human chain was formed around the perimeter of a basketball court. Salaam Ismial, state coordinator of the Union of African Students Organization, and Fields thanked the crowd for its support. ``We have to some way, somehow, find a way to live with one another,'' Ismial said. ``It's unfortunate that it took the death of a young man to bring us all together.'' Fields said he has asked teen-agers in Teaneck to stay indoors during the weekend. He said he was convinced that tensions were still high in the community, which has prided itself on being one of the first to voluntarily desegregate it schools in the 1960s. ``We haven't really reached the emotional peak of this incident yet,'' he said. ``It's going to be an emotional weekend.''

DOC.HEAD: Motorist Fined for Drenching Two People
DOC.TEXT: A city work crew drenched by a passing motorist got even by tracking the man down and getting police to charge him with malicious splashing. City worker Tom Boudreau and his partner, who were monitoring the flow of water through storm sewers, got drenched from head to foot when a car sped by and sent a 5-foot-high gush of water over them. Mad as wet hens, Boudreau said they got in their pickup truck and tracked down Robert Petrin, 24, at a drive-in window of a bank. ``I wasn't going to let him get away with that,'' Boudreau said Friday. Petrin denied deliberately splashing the workers in the March 14 incident, but police charged him under a malicious-splashing law on the city's books since 1977. A District Court judge fined Petrin $55 on April 5 when he failed to appear on the charge. There was no telephone listing for Petrin and he could not be located for comment Friday. Public Safety Chief Wayne Heikkila said most motorists don't have to worry because ``we're not going to stake out mud puddles.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Character actor Bob Lussier is turning his back on Hollywood to become a Benedictine monk. Lussier, 55, the Volkswagen driver with the three sweaty passengers in the Dial soap TV commercial and veteran of 26 films over the last quarter-century, is trading his $365,000 Hollywood hilltop home for a 10-foot-square room. He plans to spend the rest of his life at Pecos Benedictine Monastery in Pecos, N.M. He said he decided his new role after a visit to the Roman Catholic order in 1988. Lussier's movie credits include ``Johnny Got His Gun,'' ``The Killing of Sister George,'' ``Mr. Mom'' and ``Pete and Tillie.'' He's also appeared in more than 200 TV commercials. But he was troubled by the Hollywood product and what he considers its gratuitous portrayals of sex and violence, Lussier said. ``I was being called upon to do some pretty tacky stuff,'' he said. ``The care that people used to take with their productions was missing. It all seemed to change the minute the non-artistic corporations started buying film companies.'' As Brother Lussier, he will say a prayer for Hollywood decision-makers. ``I ask that they have a greater awareness of from where they've received all of their gifts,'' he said. ``Hopefully they can use those gifts in a way that will be respectable to God as they see him.''

As national television cameras rolled, hotel queen and convicted tax evader Leona Helmsley wrote a check for $42 million to the Internal Revenue Service. Mrs. Helmsley said she agreed to be videotaped by the syndicated Fox TV program ``A Current Affair'' to dispel any notion that she doesn't pay her taxes. A witness in her federal tax-evasion trial last year testified that Mrs. Helmsley said only the ``little people'' pay taxes. Mrs. Helmsley said she and her husband, Harry, have already paid $22 million in federal taxes for 1989 and another $30 million in city and state taxes. She signed the check Friday at her Harley Sandcastle hotel in Sarasota, Fla., where the couple are vacationing. As she realized she was signing a check on Friday the 13th, she said, ``My lucky day, yup, my lucky day.'' Mrs. Helmsley was convicted of evading more than $1.2 million in federal taxes between 1983 and 1985 by billing personal expenses through the Helmsley business. She was sentenced to four years in prison, fined $7.1 million and ordered to pay $1.7 million in back taxes and do 750 hours of community service. She remains free on bail pending her appeal.

Dana Carvey, the Church Lady in ``Saturday Night Live,'' was wary about the title of his first starring movie, ``Opportunity Knocks.'' ``I hate to give my critics ammunition with a title like that,'' he said. `` ... It could have been worse. It could have been called `The Really Good Movie.' Then they could say, `The Really Good Movie wasn't.''' The critics weren't as unkind as he feared. Several reviewers said the comic has a real future in films, while others found the script wanting. The film, about a small-time con man who hits it big, has drawn modest returns in the nation's theaters. Carvey, 34, is the latest of the parade of ``Saturday Night Live'' comics who have transferred to the big screen. The Church Lady was his most notable creation: he also appeared as Hans of the bodybuilding Hans and Franz, and mimicked George Bush, George Michael and George Burns.

Susanna Hoffs, former lead singer of the Bangles, is recording her first solo album since the breakup of the popular all-female rock band. Hoffs has written or co-authored 14 songs for the album, and will begin recording in several weeks, said Columbia Records spokeswoman Shelley Selover. The album, due out this summer, is being produced by David Kahne, producer of the Bangles' popular albums ``All Over The Place'' and ``Different Light.'' Hoffs will play guitar and percussion on several songs, and has been preparing through impromptu performances at local clubs.

Billionaire New York developer Donald Trump thinks the only way to win the war against drug barons is to legalize narcotics. ``We're losing badly the war on drugs,'' Trump told a Miami Herald luncheon Friday. ``You have to legalize drugs to win that war. You have to take the profit away from these drug czars.'' Tax revenues from a legalized drug trade could be spent to educate people about the dangers of drugs, Trump said in a speech to about 700 people at the newspaper's Company of the Year Awards luncheon. He blamed the country's current drug problems on politicians who ``don't have any guts.''

DOC.HEAD: Coin Found in Nuclear Reactor Vessel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ronn is cq, 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Wolf Creek nuclear power plant officials found a nickel in the water-cooled atomic reactor and are trying to determine if someone treated the vessel as a wishing well. The coin was discovered Wednesday during routine refueling and maintenace work about 25 feet down inside the reactor vessel. ``We're not sure how it got there in the first place, whether it was accidental or done on purpose,'' Ronn Smith, a spokesman for Wolf Creek Nuclear Operating Corp., said Friday. Workers tried to retrieve the nickel by lowering down a piece of lead with tape on it. They momentarily snagged it, but it broke loose and fell deeper, Smith said. Smith said analysts believe the coin will not pose a hazard or affect the operation of the reactor. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has been informed, he said. The reactor vessel lies in a refueling pool of water used to help shield workers from radioactivity and protect the fuel rods. Its top section has been removed for the replacement of fuel rods. The coin had fallen through the 23-foot-deep water and about 25 feet inside the vessel. A crane-operated bridge spans the pool and is placed directly over the reactor vessel when work is being done. Someone might have dropped the coin from the bridge or from elsewhere in the reactor containment building, Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Says Seeds From Space are Safe to Grow
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Relax, worried parents. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, its face red over a memo that fell off the vine, says it's safe for your kids to grow tomatoes from outer space. Even eat them, if they must. ``I've never heard of a killer tomato, and I don't think we've got a killer tomato plant here either,'' said Alvin Young, director of the Agriculture Department's biotechnology office. ``That's Hollywood script stuff.'' The space agency suffered a public relations crisis Friday over a memo raising the possibility that tomatoes grown from space-radiated seeds might be poisoned. Some 120,000 packets of the seeds were distributed to 58,000 teachers to be grown by their students. ``The ... project is a safe and valuable educational outreach program,'' said NASA. It said it was assured by the Agriculture Department ``there were no food safety risks associated with the tomato seeds and fruits they produced.'' But the memo from Nelson J. Ehrlich obtained by the Los Angeles Times said ``there is a remote possibility that a mutation could occur causing the plants to produce toxic fruit.'' Ehrlich is associate director for aerospace services at Oklahoma State University, which oversees NASA's school programs, and his memo was addressed to other supervisors of the project. Tomatoes, Ehrlich explained, belong to the nightshade family of plants ``notorious for the production of toxic substances such as scopolamine, atropine, belladonna, nicotine and solanine.'' Moreover, he said, foliage of the entire family is toxic. NASA reacted by calling a news conference to say all is well. It produced a new letter from Ehrlich saying, ``I have no evidence to support my statement other than the fact that the mechanism for toxin generation is present in tomatoes.'' And, said Ehrlich, he ``in no way intended to infer ... project participants would risk their lives by eating tomato fruits.'' Kenneth S. Pederson, an associate administrator of the space agency, told reporters: ``I will be happy to eat the tomatoes. My daughter is a schoolteacher ... her school is growing the tomatoes. Our whole family is going to eat the tomatoes.'' Young said raising the tomatoes is safe, but that he'd prefer that schoolchildren replant the seeds to carry out the experiment rather than eat them. The possibility of a child having an allergic reaction to tomatoes grown from the seeds is very remote, he said. ``I realize we are going to put 12 million seeds out there potentially, but I really doubt that the number is going to be big enough for us to produce a toxic mutation,'' Young said. He added there's no 100 percent assurance, however. ``There is no more danger from eating these tomatoes than from eating those you find in a grocery store,'' said Jim Alston, research director for Park Seed Co. of Greenwood, S.C., which supplied the seeds in 1984. ``There is no radiation inherent in the seeds.'' Alston said radiation counters showed ``absolutely nothing'' when the seeds were returned to Earth in January. ``I am a parent. I have kids,'' he said. ``If my kid was participating ... I would have no hesitation for them handling them.'' The seeds were in one of 57 experiment trays fastened to the outside of a 12-sided frame that had been in orbit since 1984 when it was retrieved in January by space shuttle Columbia. The satellite, named the Long Duration Exposure Facility, was testing a number of different materials to determine how they withstood the rigors of space.

DOC.HEAD: Three Europeans Arrested for Trying to Spark Religious Riots
DOC.TEXT: Two Swiss and a German were arrested for trying to foment rioting between Moslems and Christian Copts, the state-run news agency said. The Middle East News Agency, in a report Friday, but did not identify the three by name or identify the German state in question. A source at the justice ministry later said one of the detainees was West German. Officials at the Swiss and West German embassies were not immediately available because of the Easter holiday. The agency said leaflets and books calling for sectarian strife were found in the trio's apartment in Agoza, a fashionable Cairo district popular with foreigners. Last month, Moslem fundamentalists stoned and set fire to two Christian Copt churches and a youth club in southern el-Minya province. Fifteen people were wounded and fire destroyed a Christian-owned candy factory. The government said the riots were caused by a false rumor that the son of the candy factory owner, a Copt, took obscene photographs of a Moslem teen-age girl after drugging her. About 300 people, mostly Moslem extremists, were arrested in the attacks, according to the Interior Ministry. Of the nation's 55 million people, between 5 million and 6 million are Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Sulfa Drug Traces Found in Milk Samples
DOC.TEXT: A Food and Drug Administration milk survey has found traces of sulfa drugs in most of samples tested, but the agency says all were far below levels that would threaten public health. The FDA said Friday that three of the 70 samples tested also were found to contain traces of sulfamethazine, which is not approved for use in lactating cows because it may cause cancer at some levels. ``The traces, while not of safety concern, nevertheless show that a few dairy farmers or veterinarians have improperly used the drug,'' the agency said. The study suggested milk from ``only a few animals'' that are being treated improperly is reaching the market. Fifty-eight of the 70 samples contained some traces of the sulfa drugs but at levels of only 1 part per billion to 3 ppb. The agency considers 10 ppb the ``level of public health concern.'' The three samples containing sulfamethazine also showed that chemical present at concentrations of 1 ppb to 3 ppb, the agency said. The FDA said it held the dairy industry and veterinarians responsible for any illegal use of the specialized drugs. Friday's milk survey completes an FDA study started in February after the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer advocacy group, said it found milk samples in 14 metropolitan areas contaminated with antibiotics and sulfamethazine. The agency said it planned to propose eliminating sulfamethazine use in other animals used for food because the drug is a suspected carcinogen. Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., chairman of the human resources subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee, said the FDA intentionally in February when it said the sample contained no antibiotics. Weiss said the agency knew 58 were contaminated below 10 ppb. He said the subcommittee staff would investigate the agency's actions.

DOC.HEAD: A Small, Bearded Figure Looms From Brooklyn to Jerusalem
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: In the Israeli town of Kfar Chabad, a Tudor-styled anomoly rises amid the Holy Land's jumble of ancient and modern edifices. It is a replica of another building 6,000 miles away, at 770 Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn _ the headquarters of Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the 88-year-old leader of the Lubavitcher Hasidim. It is also a symbol of the fealty of Schneerson's followers. That loyalty, some political observers say, this week scuttled an attempt by the Labor Party to form an Israeli government. Two members of the Knesset refused to back Labor, citing Schneerson's opposition to trading land for peace, a cornerstone of the Labor platform. Schneerson ``has again obstructed the formation of a government in Israel,'' Allan Nadler, who teaches Jewish studies at McGill University in Montreal, complained in a column in The New York Times today. ``Once again, the parliament finds itself in the stranglehold of an Orthodox rabbi for whom the welfare of the state of Israel is entirely subordinate to parochial theological considerations,'' Nadler wrote. Rabbi Yehuda Krinsky, a spokesman for Schneerson, denied that Schneerson had issued any dictum to the rebellious legislators. The rebbe, or grand rabbi, had not talked to either, he said, and had taken no sides in Israel's political crisis. Schneerson did comment, obliquely, on the land-for-peace issue in a speech several weeks ago. And one of the two legislators, Rabbi Avraham Verdiger, called the rebbe's office to ask if Schneerson had changed his position. Told he had not, Verdiger repudiated Labor ``on his own initiative,'' Krinsky said. ``Lubavitch has not been involved in any of the political horse-trading that's going on.'' Schneerson's name has come up in previous Israeli controversies; opponents claimed that he was behind efforts to amend the law so the converts of non-Orthodox rabbis would not gain automatic citizenship in Israel. In the United States, his followers have earned the enmity of other Jewish groups by supporting moments of silent prayer in public schools, and by pressing for the right to erect Hanukkah menorahs in public places. The man at the center of these disputes is a small figure, distinguished by his black fedora, white beard and penetrating blue eyes. Born in Russia, an immigrant in 1941, he has never been to Israel. In fact, apart from twice-yearly visits to his father-in-law's grave in Queens, he has not left Brooklyn at all since he took office in 1950. Schneerson is the seventh in the line of Lubavitcher rebbes going back to his great-great-great-great-grandfather, Rabbi Schneur Zalman, an acolyte of the founder of Hasidism, the Baal Shem Tov. The Lubavitchers, like other Hasidim, are pious folk. The men wear black and are bearded; the women cut their hair and wear wigs after marriage. But unlike the others, the Lubavitchers are outward-looking, eager to persuade other Jews to become more observant. Schneerson has presided over a rapid expansion of the Lubavitcher universe. More than 1,000 ``Chabad'' houses have been established around the world to spread the word; the rebbe's speeches, sometimes extending six hours, are sent by satellite to cable systems around the world; recreational vans, known as ``Jewish tanks,'' roam the country to promote Jewish ritual. Lubavitcher officials claim a million followers around the world; others dispute that figure but agree that the movement is influential. ``Lubavitch is the single most powerful movement in the Jewish world,'' said Rabbi Irving Greenburg, an Orthodox rabbi and critic of the Lubavitchers who heads the Center for Learning and Leadership. Schneerson is the movement's soul. More than 125 volumes of his talks, writings and correspondence have been published. His pictures hang everywhere in Israel. His advice is sought on all matters _ whether a couple should marry; the solution to a business question; even, says Krinsky, the answer to complex mathematical problems. His followers recall seemingly miraculous consequences of Schneerson's suggestions _ lives that were saved, babies that were born, marriages that were made. These stories have led some to ask whether the rebbe is actually the messiah, come to Earth to redeem the Jews. Such talk outrages other Jewish leaders. Schneerson has never claimed to be the messiah; Krinsky says only that if the messiah should come, the rebbe _ said to be a descendent of King David's _ would be qualified. Krinsky says there can be no dispute about one thing: ``There's no greater spiritual leader in the world Jewish community.''

DOC.HEAD: Arson Ruled Out in Hotel Fire That Killed Nine
DOC.TEXT: Fire investigators have been able to pinpoint where a hotel fire that killed nine elderly people started, but not how. They have ruled out arson, however, in the April 6 fire at the residential Fontana Hotel. ``We have sifted and gone through practically every foot of dirt and debris that was in the building. It was not a set fire,'' Malcolm Brady, chief of the Miami office of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said Friday. Nearly 100 residents were left homeless by the deadliest fire ever in the oceanside city. Investigators are certain the fire started in a crawl space below the third floor of the 102-room hotel where residents had reported a water leak and plumbers had been working less than 24 hours earlier, Brady said. However, after more than 250 interviews, expert analysis of burn patterns and a search by an accelerant-sniffing dog, state and federal fire investigators failed to pinpoint the cause of the blaze. ``It's tremendously frustrating for all of us to arrive on a scene that's taken nine lives and not to be able to come to you conclusively and say this is what caused it,'' Brady said. The blaze was so intense that temperatures reached more than 1,200 degrees, steel melted and and crucial evidence was destroyed, Brady said. ``It probably smoldered in that crawl space for a number of hours, literally consuming itself until it ignited,'' Brady said. ``Some of the evidence we needed is gone forever.'' Authorities have identified all nine bodies recovered from the three-story hotel located between the city's trendy art deco district and a strip of luxury high-rise condominiums. Investigators don't expect the death toll to rise. Five other occupants reported as missing after the fire have since been located. All nine victims, ranging in age from 75 to 93, died of smoke inhalation, said Dr. Katherine Berg of Dade County medical examiner's office. More than 60 searchers, including arson experts from the ATF and city and state fire marshal's offices, took part in the investigation, and workers continued to comb through the blackened shell of the building Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Export Credit Guarantee Program Suspended
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department says a billion-dollar credit program that allows Iraq to buy U.S. farm commodities has been suspended until USDA completes an investigation of possible financial irregularities. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder, who oversees international affairs and commodity programs, said in a brief statement Friday that the department ``is continuing its administrative review, begun several months ago, into transactions relating to past (credit) programs with Iraq.'' Crowder said Iraqi authorities are cooperating in the investigation and that a U.S. team will be in Baghdad soon to continue the discussions. Meanwhile, he said, additional commitments of export credits ``will await the conclusion of this administrative review.'' The action involves the Export Credit Guarantee Program, which provides short-term credit guarantees for up to three years. The government does not lend any money but acts as a back-up for exporters and commercial banks. Kelly Shipp, press secretary for Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, said the departmental team plans to be in Iraq next week. She said the irregularities appear to involve pricing and shipping procedures. She did not offer specifics. For the current fiscal year that began last Oct. 1, Iraq was allocated a credit line of $1 billion, she said. Only $500 million has been used, and the rest is being held up until the investigation is completed. Shipp said the investigation began last October and has nothing to do with another snarl of financial problems involving Iraq's credit operation with Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, or BNL, in Rome. In that case, BNL's branch in Atlanta, Ga., allegedly ran up a $3 billion credit exposure with Iraq, Italy's Treasury Minister Guido Carli said last September. The Agriculture Department's export credit program was said to have guaranteed part of that amount. The Justice Department and others reportedly are investigating the BNL case.

DOC.HEAD: White House Hopes New Visa Policy Will End Boycott Threat
DOC.TEXT: The White House is hoping a new 10-day visa that won't require foreigners to reveal their AIDS status will end threats of a boycott of an upcoming international conference on the disease in San Francisco. But it was unclear whether the action will be enough to satisfy critics of U.S. immigration restrictions. ``I don't know whether they'll view this as sufficient,'' said June Osborn, chairwoman of the National Commission on AIDS. ``But it's something we can point to and say `Look, we're trying,' and in that I think it will be a reassuring signal to the rest of the world.'' Members of Congress also said they were encouraged by the administration's action creating the new visa, announced Friday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. But they also said the move was only a first step. ``More needs to be done,'' said Rep. J. Roy Rowland, D-Ga., sponsor of legislation that would clear the way for the administration to take AIDS off a list of diseases used to bar entry to the United States. Dozens of organizations worldwide have said they will boycott the San Francisco AIDS conference in June in protest of U.S. immigration policy that restricts entry of people infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. The World Health Organization, an arm of the United Nations, is considering whether to withdraw its co-sponsorship of the conference. Michael Merson, acting head of WHO's global program on AIDS, said from Geneva on Friday night that he could not comment until he and other officials reviewed the administration's action. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., said that while the new visa was ``a first step,'' he was troubled that it would be available only for those attending certain conferences deemed by the secretary of Health and Human Services to be ``in the public interest.'' ``Will the administration be limiting visas to censor meetings they don't approve of?'' he asked. Waxman, a co-sponsor of Rowland's bill and chairman of a House health subcommittee, said his panel will hold hearings on the legislation later this month. Administration sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the White House has no plans to support the bill, and supporters have said it has little chance to pass without such backing. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said it was premature for the administration to take a position on the bill. ``Rather than wait for what tends to be the molasses-like speed of Congress to debate and vote on a piece of legislation, we are taking actions that are immediate and effective,'' she said. The administration has said there is little it can do to ease immigration restrictions on people with AIDS because of an amendment, offered by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and passed by Congress in 1987. The legislation put AIDS on the list of contagious diseases that can be used to exclude foreigners. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, who has authority to determine which conferences are in the public interest, immediately certified two events under the new visa policy: the Sixth International Conference on AIDS to be held June 20-24 in San Francisco; and the 19th International Congress of the World Federation of Hemophilia to be held Aug. 14-19 in Washington, D.C. ``It is important that we support the free exchange of scientific information across international boundaries,'' Sullivan said. ``In particular, when we confront a worldwide public health threat like AIDS, researchers need to be able to share their findings quickly.'' The current waiver policy INS adopted last year will remain in effect, the agency said. That allows people infected with HIV to visit the United States for up to 30 days to attend educational or medical conferences, to receive medical treatment, to visit close family members or to conduct temporary business activities, as long as the person is otherwise admissible. INS had been expediting that process for people who want to attend the San Francisco and Washington conferences.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Chief Says DC Situation Improving
DOC.TEXT: The drug situation in the nation's capital is improving, but city officials are not using all the available federal money, says national drug chief William J. Bennett. ``The situation remains far from acceptable, to be sure. But at the same time, some things are moving in the right direction,'' the national drug control policy director said at a news conference said Friday. ``I think it's fair to say the record is mixed, spotty, incomplete _ not nearly as good as anyone would like, but also not so bad as many people might imagine,'' Bennett said in assessing progress of a year-old federal-local anti-drug effort in the District of Columbia. Bennett said the city's record murder rate in 1989 was ``a bitter disappointment to all concerned,'' but that the overall situation was not as negative as some had expected. ``I'm not here to declare failure,'' Bennett said. ``By a sober assessment of the merits, I don't think that's warranted.'' In 1989, 438 persons were killed in the nation's capital, and police blamed a flourishing drug trade for more than 60 percent of the slayings. Bennett said signs of progress include decreases in the number of people arrested who test positive for drugs and of hospital emergency room patients who mention drug use. But the drug policy coordinator said more progress might have been made if the city had taken better advantage of available federal money. Bennett said, for example, that the city failed to spend 85 percent of $2.3 million in funding for special National Guard anti-crime assistance. In all, federal funding to city anti-drug efforts has increased by 40 percent since last September and now is at a level two-and-one-half times the national average, Bennett said. ``We chose D.C. for this effort because D.C. was on fire,'' Bennett said. ``Washington remains a federal priority in the war on drugs.'' But Bennett said federal officials will expect improvement from the city in several areas, including moving forward on prison construction and drug treatment centers. D.C. Mayor Marion Barry is awaiting trial on cocaine possession and perjury charges stemming from his January arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Victim Who Gave Birth Dies
DOC.TEXT: A woman cancer patient who rejected chemical and radiation treatment so she could give birth to a healthy baby has died. Linda Babcock, 41, gave birth to a 5-pound 6-ounce boy Feb. 23 while battling an inoperable lung cancer known as oat cell carcinoma. She had rejected treatment for fear of damaging the baby and refused to have an abortion. The baby, Jesse, is doing fine. ``He's a beautiful son. I'll find a way to take care of him,'' Mrs. Babcock's husband, George, said Friday night. ``The baby kept her going,'' he said. Shortly after she gave birth, Mrs. Babcock said in an interview from her room at St. Joseph Medical Center in Bloomington that she didn't believe she had cancer anymore. ``I feel so much better. I can breathe. I could tell it was there before. It felt like something cutting off my air, taking my life,'' she had said. ``I'm confident of living, of beating the cancer ... The baby saved me from death as I saved him.'' Her doctors had been skeptical that she'd be able to deliver a healthy baby without treatment. After she did, they said her cancer still was very malignant and that if it went untreated, her chances for survival appeared slim. ``After the birth, she went downhill real fast,'' her husband said. She was hospitalized for almost a week before she returned Thursday to her home here in rural east-central Illinois, Babcock said. He said she refused radiology and chemotherapy treatment to the end. She had survived pregnancy by adopting a nutritional diet of organically grown vegetables and fruits, carrot juice and vitamin pills. Mrs. Babcock had three other children.

DOC.HEAD: Toll-Free Lines Stay Open for Last-Minute Taxpayers
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service will keep its toll-free telephone lines open through this afternoon to assist taxpayers rushing to meet the midnight Monday deadline for filing their 1989 tax returns. The IRS said Friday that telephoned tax questions also will be answered into the evening Monday. Numbers to call are listed in the instructions for filling out Forms 1040, 1040A and 1040EZ. Taxpayers with Touch-Tone telephone service may use the IRS Tele-Tax lines 24 hours a day. Tele-Tax is a system of tape-recorded explanations of more than 140 specific topics, including pensions, dependents and the child-care credit. Phone numbers and topics also are listed in the IRS instructions. The IRS expects one of every five tax returns to be filed next week _ 23 million out of 111 million due this year. Four of every five returns have been qualifying for refunds. Those who wait until the final hours to file will have to wait another eight weeks or so before receiving any refund. When a return is filed on time, the IRS is required by law to pay interest on any refund that is not paid within 45 days.
DOC.HEAD: Insect Incinerator Recall Reissued
DOC.TEXT: One importer of a major brand of electric bug killers has reissued a recall for four of its models, a government agency says.. The back yard devices are being recalled because they present a potential fire hazard, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Friday. Few consumers have returned them as originally requested last summer, the commission said. Dead insects accumulating in the devices and high humidity can cause them to catch fire. The company knows of 20 such fires that caused property damage. The recall involves Charmglow bug killer models 071512, 073425, 074001 and 078012. The CPSC said just 195 of the 8,000 bug killers that were sold nationwide in 1987 have been returned. Buyers should contact the importer _ Allied Tube and Conduit Corp. of Harvey, Ill. _ at 1-800-558-5502 for directions on how to return the bug killers for a full refund.
DOC.HEAD: Pacifiers Recalled Because of Danger of Suffocation
DOC.TEXT: The distributor of a baby pacifier is recalling more than 47,000 of them because they may present a suffocation or strangulation hazard to young children, the government says. Consolidated Stores of Columbus, Ohio, is recalling 47,520 of its ``bib to bowl'' pacifiers because they don't have ventilation holes in the guards or shields as required by law, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Friday. The pacifiers were sold nationwide from May through November 1989 at Odd Lots or Big Lots Stores in packages labeled in English and French ``bib to bowl, Sterilized Pacifier, birth to 24 months, 1852037.'' Consumers should return the pacifiers to the store where purchased for a full refund or contact Consolidated Stores at 614-278-6800.
DOC.HEAD: Experiment May Light Up the Sky
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the north-central United States and central Canada may see a rainbow of colors in the night sky before dawn on Easter Sunday if a National Aeronautics and Space Administration experiment proceeds as planned. NASA announced that the Pegsat satellite would release a canister of barium at 1:36 a.m. EDT Sunday 362 miles above the earth over northern Canada, between Churchill and Yellowknife, if conditions are right for the test. The barium should form a yellowish cloud, which will change to green and white, then fade while a purple streak grows vertically, NASA said. The experiment is aimed at studying the interactions of the barium with the electric and magnetic fields of the earth and with other characteristics of space at that altitude, NASA said. Scientists at several sites in the United States and Canada will be watching the barium cloud. The Pegsat satellite was released from the unique winged Pegasus space vehicle launched from a B-52 on April 5.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Sadly Accept Soviet Apology for Massacre of 15,000 Polish Officers
DOC.TEXT: Poles tearfully accepted the Soviet Union's apology for the massacre of almost 15,000 Polish officers during World War II, but demanded reparations and more details of the killings. ``It's good that criminals admit their crimes,'' Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said in Gdansk Friday. He called the Soviet admission ``an act of moral justice, which has been awaited for a long time.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave President Wojciech Jaruzelski documents showing that the secret police of Soviet leader Josef Stalin killed the Polish officers on Soviet territory during World War II. Jaruzelski, on an official visit to Moscow, was to visit Katyn today. The area is in the Smolensk forest in Western Russia, where at least 4,000 of the officers are buried in mass graves. The Soviet admission ended nearly 50 years of official Soviet denials and had been almost a prerequisite for improved Polish-Soviet relations. The Soviet Union had previously insisted that Nazi Germany was responsible for the massacre. ``I awfully regret that my mother could not live until this day,'' said Wanda Zadrozna, crying as she recalled her father's murder in the Russian woods. Ms. Zadrozna said her father, Piotr, was taken prisoner by the Russians in 1939, when she was 12 years old. She said her family received three letters from her father over the next year, but never heard from him after 1940. She said her mother, Helena Krahelska, kept a pair of shoes and a clean shirt ready for him for nine years, despite growing evidence that he had been killed. In 1943, Nazis invading the Soviet Union unearthed mass graves in Katyn filled with the bodies of the Polish officers. They had been shot in the back of the head and their bodies stacked one on top of the other. ``This news was so horrible, no one wanted to believe it. We treated it as propaganda,'' Mrs. Zadrozna said. But in 1948, Mrs. Krahelska gave up hope that her husband would return home. She died eight years ago, never having been able to visit her husband's gravesite in the Soviet Union. ``Whatever happens now, it is good that the truth will be finally written in history,'' Ms. Zadrozna said. Bozena Lojek, who helps lead an organization of victims' relatives called the Katyn Family, said she felt ``great joy now that after so many years the truth has been revealed.'' Her late husband's father was one of the officers who was killed. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said Poland recognizes the significance of the official Soviet statement, but wanted more questions answerd. ``We await an explanation of all the `blank spots' in our common history, which the Katyn crime symbolizes for us,'' she said. The bodies of more than 4,200 officers, interned by the Soviets at Kozielsk, were uncovered in the forest. But the remains of another 10,000 officers who were captive at camps in Starobielsk and Ostashkow have never been found, and their families still demand to know of their exact fate. Walesa said there must be ``punishment of those guilty of the genocide,'' reparations for the officers' families and access for Poles to the victims' graves. In Friday's government statement, issued as Gorbachev met with Jaruzelski, the Soviet Union clearly tied together the fates of the officers. ``Recently, documents have been discovered which indirectly but convincingly testify that thousands of Polish officers who died in the Smolensk woods half a century ago became victims of (Stalin's secret police chief Lavrenti) Beria and his henchmen,'' Tass quoted Gorbachev as saying at the meeting. The officers were regarded as the cream of Poland's pre-war society and many observers have said the Soviets may have consdidered them a threat to the future Communist leaders of Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Town Gets Economic Boost From Crinkly, Colorful Easter Grass
DOC.TEXT: This quiet industrial town once had all its economic eggs in one basket _ brick-making. Now, part of its future is pinned to baskets of eggs. Not just any eggs. Easter eggs. More specifically, the colorful plastic grass that goes underneath them. Mount Union, in central Pennsylvania, is home to one of the nation's leading producers of Easter basket grass. The plant where the crinkly grass is made helped revitalize the town's economy when it opened in 1979, a time when brickyard kilns were cooling from a downturn in building. The 105 employees of the Bleyer Industries Inc. factory have a busy season from November to a couple of weeks before Easter. But the plant runs all year round, branching into tinted plastic wrap at other times of the year with a reduced staff. ``We made 18 million bags of grass this season,'' said manager Frank Lukens. ``We've been making about a million more bags each year.'' Liquid polypropylene arrives at the plant by rail and is converted to sheets of tinted plastic, then stretched and run through 10 machines with slits spaced one-eighth inch apart, Lukens said. The grass kinks when the tension is relaxed, then handfuls are stuffed into 1-, 2-, 3-, or 4-ounce bags adorned with bunnies, or the grass is rolled into 80-pound bales. The grass comes in pink, yellow and green. During the Easter rush, the plant runs 10 hours a day, six days a week. Some large chocolate and gift makers, such as Russell Stover Candies in Kansas City, Mo., make their own grass to accompany their Easter products. More than 6,000 people lived in Mount Union in the middle of the century, turning clay from nearby mountains into bricks. But the population steadily fell to the present level of 3,000 as three large brick factories closed over the last 20 years, the last in January. The town went scrambling for replacement businesses, and borough manager Frank Stasenko said it has succeeded in diversifying its economy. In addition to the Easter grass factory, Mount Union is home to a plant that makes fiberglass tanks for gasoline stations and another that makes pipe fittings. ``We've been as low as we're going to get,'' Stasenko said. Lukens doesn't like to talk about the plant, and no tours are allowed. He won't say why the company prefers to keep a low profile. One reason for the silence could be to discourage competitors from entering the Easter grass market, Stasenko suggested. Another, he said, might be concern from environmentalists over what to do with the plastic grass when Easter is over. For that, Lukens has a solution. ``Save it. My mother still has the Easter grass from the basket I got when I was four years old,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: King Expresses Grief at Loss of Life
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra, in his first reference to the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters, today expressed grief at the loss of life, but he said politics in Nepal had ``taken a new turn.'' In a nationwide broadcast, however, the king made no reference to meeting Friday with the principal opposition leader. During the talks, the king reportedly agreed to the formation of a new government led by the opposition. ``The loss of life and destruction of property have saddened us. We pray for the eternal peace of those who lost their lives in tragic circumstances,'' Birendra said in a television and radio broadcast on Nepal's new year's day. The government has said at least 10 people died and 107 were injured on April 6, when security forces fired on 200,000 people protesting for a multiparty system. Witnesses said at least 200 people were killed. Two days later, Birendra submitted to demands from the opposition alliance that led the 7-week-old pro-democracy movement and lifted a 29-year-old ban on political parties in his Himalayan kingdom. ``We have upheld the tradition of respecting the popular will and fulfilling the aspirations of the people,'' Birendra said. ``Politics in Nepal has now taken a new turn.'' But in his brief speech Birenda did not mention his talks with Ganesh Man Singh of the Nepali Congress Party. The hourlong meeting was the first between Birendra and Singh since the pro-democracy movement burgeoned in February. In a statement the opposition said Friday the king had agreed to allow the alliance to head a government until general elections are called. It did not say when balloting would be held. Singh said the king agreed to discuss on Sunday eight other conditions set by the alliance for participating in any interim government. Those include dissolution of the ational assembly and constitutional reforms. Birenda said a proposed commission on constitutional reform ``will consult elements of society professing different political views in the course of preparing its report.'' The constitution gives the king absolute judicial, executive and legislative powers. The current government is largely a rubber-stamp body controlled by the king, and the national assembly is a partyless single-chamber body dominated by the king's nominees. ``We are confident that proper understanding and respect for the norms of democracy by all Nepalese will safeguard the values and ideals of democracy in Nepal for all time to come,'' Birendra said. ``May Nepal and all Nepalese live in security and be able to maintain their self-respect,'' said the 44-year-old Harvard educated monarch. The Nepali Congress Party president, K.P. Bhattarai, said Birenda's speech was ``not complete. We expected announcement agreeing to all the eight points and at least a mention of those in the speech.'' ``We are not much disappointed because the liberal trend is there,'' Bhattarai said. The Nepali Congress Party formed Nepal's only Western-style parliamentary government in May 1959, but was dismissed 20 months later by Birendra's father, King Mahendra, on grounds of corruption and maladministration. Except for that brief period, Nepal has been ruled by the royal Shah dynasty or the hereditary Rana prime ministers since the mid-18th century.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Feds Say Florida Company Provided Faulty Parts For Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators are examining allegations that a Florida company provided faulty parts for the space shuttle and several weapons systems, a report published today said. Impala Electronics Inc. of Tampa, Fla., is being investigated on charges it switched labels on resistors used to regulate currents in electronic control systems, The New York Times reported. A Pentagon memo dated Oct. 16 said the relabeling scheme involved buying inferior quality resistors and then changing their markings or codings, the Times said. The government recently tested 10 resistors supplied by Impala and nine failed, the Times said. But the newspaper said there is no evidence that the resistors have caused safety problems on the space shuttle, including that of the Challenger, which exploded after takeoff Jan. 28, 1986, killing all seven crew members. The Tampa office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Defense Department's Criminal Investigative Service and the National Aeronautics and Space Administrations's inspector general are conducting the investigation, the Times said. It said Impala and its president, Joseph A. Pistone, are targets. A lawyer who represents Impala would not comment and Pistone did not return several telephone calls left with his secretary, the Times said. The Times said Impala doesn't deal directly with the government. Instead, Impala distributes resistors made by other companies to the Pentagon or space agency contractors or subcontractors. According to the memorandum, these companies include the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Boeing, Raytheon, the Martin Marietta Corporation and Honeywell Inc., the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: 100 Injured As Tornado Hits Bangladesh
DOC.TEXT: A tornado tore through six villages in eastern Bangladesh, injuring at least 100 people, blowing down houses and toppling trees, news reports said today. The twister devastated the villages in Brahmanbaria district, 50 miles east of Dhaka, said the daily Ittefaq. At least 100 people were injured when the tornado toppled about 300 mud-and-straw dwellings late Thursday night, the newspaper said. Crops also were damaged. Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries in the world, is often buffeted by natural disasters. Summer floods, cyclones and storms kill hundreds of people every year. At least 166 people were killed and 1,600 injured in storms that battered parts of the country late last month and in early April.

DOC.HEAD: Good Friday Marks Beginning of Easter Celebrations
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II led a torchlight procession through the Colosseum in one of many Good Friday ceremonies worldwide marking Jesus' death on the cross. The pope was to celebrate the Easter Vigil tonight and an open-air Mass on Easter Sunday in St. Peter's Square. Thousands holding candles in red paper cones watched Friday night as the pontiff carried a 5-foot-high cross from the Colosseum to the edge of the ancient Roman Forum, evoking the tortures Jesus suffered as he walked to his crucifixion on Calvary Hill in Jerusalem. The event was broadcast to millions throughout the world and seen in the Soviet Union for the first time. Another procession, the 146th annual re-enactment at an ancient Indian ceremonial site in Mexico, was attended by hundreds of thousands. Thousands of pilgrims also retraced the traditional route of Jesus' death in Jerusalem's Old City, In the Philippines, more than 20 Filipino penitents were nailed to crosses for up to 10 minutes and others whipped themselves bloody. The Philippines is Asia's only predominantly Christian nation. ``All of us who belong to the priestly people of the new covenant gaze upon the cross, with veneration and recollection,'' John Paul said in a brief Italian-language speech following the procession of the Via Crucis, or Way of the Cross. ``We draw nourishment from the impenetrable mystery, which human words cannot describe.'' The pope, wearing white robes and a crimson cape trimmed with gold, carried before him a slender black cross made of lightweight wood. He was followed by two men bearing torches and a group of cardinals and other priests. At each of the 14 stops representing the stages of Jesus' suffering, men and women read meditations written by the Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, Michel Sabbah. They asked for spiritual blessings for modern Christians. Thousands of nuns, tourists and Romans outside the Colosseum prayed and sang in Latin as the pope walked slowly between the stations. A large cross made of candles flickered inside the Colosseum. The Good Friday ceremonies mark the most solemn day of the year for Christians, who celebrate Jesus' resurrection on Easter Sunday. Pope Paul VI revived the papal tradition of re-enacting the Way of the Cross in 1964 after an interruption of nearly a century following the creation of the modern Italian state. Earlier, in a Good Friday message issued to Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, the pope appealed anew for a halt to the ``fratricidal'' fighting in Lebanon. ``The drama of Lebanon must end ... Lebanon must live again,'' said the telegram, sent on the 15th anniversary of the start of Lebanon's civil war. The pontiff also celebrated a ceremony in St. Peter's Basilica Friday afternoon marking Jesus' death. Just after noon, John Paul heard the confessions of 12 pilgrims in St. Peter's Basilica, continuing a Good Friday tradition he began 11 years ago to emphasize the importance of the sacrament penance.

DOC.HEAD: A Mayor and His Jetty, Together on Easter
DOC.TEXT: Andy Valence will stand proud Easter Sunday as the jetty he fought so hard for protects his friends and neighbors on Grand Isle. Valence is mayor of the tiny island community of 2,000, and the rock jetty that keeps the Gulf of Mexico at a distance is a rare victory over natural and man-made forces eating away at Louisiana's coastline. At sunrise on Easter, services are planned for a spot that last summer was knee-deep in the waters of the Gulf, waters that later threatened an island motel. Valence was considered misguided, at best, when he proposed building a rock jetty to keep the Gulf from destroying the island. The experts shot him down, but he persevered and after years of work recently completed much of the structure. Now, Valence said, ``the rocks are doing exactly what they are supposed to be doing.'' Louisiana loses 30 to 50 square miles of coastline every year, an acre every 15 minutes, or an area the size of Rhode Island every 30 years. Nowhere along the coast was the loss more apparent than about 50 miles south of New Orleans at Grand Isle, the state's only inhabited barrier island, a strip of sand that served as headquarters for Jean Lafitte when the buccaneer was the scourge of English and Spanish shipping almost 200 years ago. Grand Isle, along with the rest of Louisiana's coast, once was replenished annually by sediment washing down the Mississippi River, but man built locks and dams for commerce, and lined the lower river with levees to protect communities on its banks. Nature continues to send hurricanes against the island, but the changes prevent silt from replenishing the sand that washes away. Experts said hard structures such as jetties and seawalls were self-defeating, that the waves would find the weak spots and wash away the sand there. They pointed to failures in Galveston, Texas, around the Florida peninsula and up the coast to Fire Island, N.Y. Valence spent seven years in solitary study of winds and tides, weather patterns and the different rates of scouring action on seashells. He taught himself enough physics to answer the questions he asked himself and enough math and geometry to implement the answers. ``While most people were sleeping or watching Johnny Carson, I was out there walking a levee which has been under water since 1985,'' he said. ``I'd just sit there on the beach and study and think. I guess I looked like a vagrant to some people.'' Eventually, Valence designed a ``T'' shaped jetty, the arms intended to disrupt the relocation of wave energy. He planned it to let 15 percent of the energy penetrate the barrier, with a plastic mat under the jetty to prevent undercutting. It took him a year to get a permit to build the jetty. He raised $135,000 by charging $500 to put people's names on rocks. Then, he sent Grand Isle High School art students to a marble company to learn how to engrave names on rocks. The state paid $250,000 and the federal government put up $100,000 for the jetty. So far, the jetty has cost $456,000, but the underpinning must be completed, and there are other costs to be met. Valence plans a ``rock concert'' to raise more money. ``If I had a horse and some dogs, I'd do a dog and pony show,'' he said. Critics fear the jetty is rebuilding the middle of the island at the expense of a state park at the eastern end, robbing the park of drifting sand. ``It won't cause erosion at the park, but it will slow accretion,'' Valence said. ``The park already extends out 200 feet. They don't need another grain of sand.'' The jetty has yet to face its most severe test _ a major hurricane.

DOC.HEAD: Police Appeal to Mugged Subway Gunman to Come Forward
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with police searching for missing wallet; picks up 5th graf pvs, `But police...
DOC.TEXT: Police appealed to the man who shot and killed a subway robber to come forward, saying they know he was a victim. ``This is not the Bernhard Goetz case,'' Brooklyn Chief of Detectives Joseph DeMartino said Friday. ``This is an individual who is clearly being robbed, has lost his property, has been beaten and draws a weapon and shoots his assailant.'' The man pulled a gun and opened fire on a group of attackers Thursday night in the New York City borough of Brooklyn, killing one of them and scattering the others, police said. The man got off at the next stop and vanished. Detectives combed through trash cans and along subway tracks and gutters in downtown Brooklyn searching for the gunman's wallet, which was stolen during the struggle, according to witnesses. Police also said a friend of the shot robber might have taken the wallet. The shooting was being compared to the 1984 Goetz subway shooting case. As in the Goetz case, the shooter was white and the youths he confronted were black. But police don't believe Thursday's shooting was racially motivated. And they noted that Goetz had not been robbed _ he believed he was about to be _ while several witnesses Thursday saw a gang of youths attack the gunman. Goetz, now 42, made headlines when he shot four youths in a subway car on the morning of Dec. 22, 1984. He claimed the group was about to mug him; the youths claimed they were panhandling. Goetz fled but surrendered to police in New Hampshire nine days later. He eventually was acquitted of attempted murder, but convicted of a weapons possession charge. He wound up serving 8{ months in jail after losing a lengthy legal battle that reached the U.S. Supreme Court. Police did not know yet whether the gunman in Thursday's shooting was carrying his weapon legally. The slain robber was identified as Ricky Pickett, 25. A watch with a torn band, believed to belong to the gunman, was found in Pickett's pocket, police Capt. Stephen Davis said. Pickett, who also used five other names, had served jail time for some of his half-dozen robbery convictions dating back to 1980, according to police sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The subway shooter was described as 45 to 55 years old, 5 feet 10 inches, with gray hair, wearing a beige raincoat and brown pants and carrying a canvas gym bag. The shooting occurred in front of at least 20 people, while Pickett was among a group of 14 youths heading to a Times Square disco, police said. At least one of the two independent witnesses told police they saw members of the group passing a gun around, Davis said. The gun was not used in the robbery, police said, but a witness said the robbers had a retractable razor. The four or five robbers grabbed the man, went through his pockets, took his wallet and threw him back on the seat, police said. ``The male fought them off, kicking out at them, and witnesses state he drew a gun from his waistband and shot one of his assailants,'' DeMartino said. One bullet hit Pickett in the chest, police said. The path of the other two shots was not known. The mortally wounded Pickett, and the other men, fled into the next car. The gunman and most of the youths left at the next station, leaving Pickett dying on the train.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Logging Rally Draws Thousands
LaserPhoto PD1
DOC.TEXT: Loggers, mill workers and their families fear they will be forgotten under an emerging national policy to limit logging of never-cut timber to protect spotted owls. On Friday, 8,000 to 10,000 people rallied in Pioneer Square to protest the policy. Clad in yellow caps and ribbons, the ralliers heard U.S. Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., tell them the agenda of environmentalists could be condensed into two words: ``No jobs.'' Environmentalists argue that old-growth timber in the Northwest must be protected to save the northern spotted owl from extinction. They say the forest owl cannot survive outside the complex ecosystem anchored by centuries-old trees. But Oregonians at the rally, and some of their elected officials, echoed Packwood's economic fears. ``We think this potentially could have the largest impact on the Northwest since the Depression, economically,'' Douglas County Commissioner Doug Robertson said. ``It's come to the point that if we don't stand up and be counted, we're going to suffer the consequences, and the consequences are going to be severe.'' A panel of scientists recommended to Congress on April 4 that millions of acres of Northwest old-growth forest be set aside as owl habitat. The exact locations of the habitat are under study. Packwood wants Congress to reduce the amount of recommended forest that would be set aside for the owl. It's up to Congress to decide by this fall how much of the region's old-growth timber can be cut and how much owl habitat should be protected. Organizers of the rally said 350 businesses around the state closed so their employees could attend. Some schools gave students excused absences so they could join their parents. Officials of Douglas County, rated by the U.S. Forest Service as the most timber-dependent county in Oregon, gave 25 to 30 county workers the day off with pay so they could attend the rally. In the Linn County community of Sweet Home, 105 businesses closed and about 500 people made the 85-mile trip to Portland. Bob and Susan Kasting, owners of the Busy Bee restaurant in Sweet Home, joined the caravan. Kasting said a shutdown of the timber industry would devastate his business. ``If they can't work, they can't eat,'' he said. Police reported several scuffles between environmentalists and timber industry supporters on the edge of the crowd. The odor of smoke bombs wafted across the square. Portland police spokesman Dave Simpson said officers took three people who appeared to be timber industry supporters into custody. The three seemed to be intoxicated and were held until they could sober up, but weren't charged with any crimes, Simpson said. During the rally, dozens of log trucks circled downtown on the freeways, occasionally blowing their horns. Evelyn Badger of the Oregon Lands Coalition, a pro-industry group that organized the rally, said Congress would be asked to set aside forest land specifically for timber harvests. ``We are the dirty-hands people who feed, clothe and shelter this nation,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The new couple at the condominium complex are doing just ducky, thanks. But the neighbors aren't too happy. Ever since two small mallards showed up, 197 residents of the Laurelmont complex have been trying to figure how to make them leave. The male paddles around the swimming pool's deep end. The female sits on her eggs in the bushes behind a chaise lounge. Now, Orange County health officials are threatening to shut down the pool just as the weather is heating up because the chlorine level is unbalanced. But the ducks are untouchable. State and federal law says no one can ``tamper, bother, harass, move or kill any migratory birds, their babies or nests,'' said Linda Evans, executive director of an organization called Pacific Wildlife Project. Violation of the law could bring a one-year prison term or a $10,000 fine. ``It's mushrooming into quite a problem,'' said Lisle Starbuck, vice president of Assured Property Management, the complex manager. ``I have homeowners who want to use the pool (who aren't happy) swimming around in duck doo and others with guns who want to protect the ducks.'' The next step is for a warden from the state Department of Fish and Game to come out and make a decision.

In the future, critics of artist Jim Elniski may call this year his hair period. Elniski is busy collecting hair from 96 beauty salons and barber shops for a 9-foot-by-12-foot room he plans to wallpaper in hair. The work will be called ``The Neighborhood.'' ``Neighborhoods are a categorical way of organizing people but also separating them,'' Elniski said Friday. ``The hair is a common denominator.'' Elniski, 39, has persuaded hair cutters across the city to turn over their clippings. He has collected about eight bushels of hair so far. The artist plans to glue hair to four walls, creating an abstract design he will set, probably with unscented hair spray. A photograph of each hair-cutting establishment will be displayed on the outside of the room, along with a listing of the neighborhoods they are in. When people walk into the room through a door cut in one of the walls, Elniski hopes they will realize their ``shared animal nature.'' ``We all, just in being alive, create this substance,'' he said. ``We all have this hair.''

DOC.HEAD: Light Earthquake Occurs on US-Canadian Border
DOC.TEXT: A ``light'' earthquake has occurred along the U.S.-Canadian border, the U.S. Geological Survey said early today. The tremor occurred at 10:33 p.m. local time, or 1:33 a.m. EDT, about 50 miles southeast of Vancouver, British Columbia, and 20 miles northeast of Bellingham, Wash., said USGS spokesman Donald Finley. Earthquake monitors at the survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., recorded the movement at a preliminary magnitude of 4.5 on the Richter scale, Finley said. That magnitude is considered ``light,'' meaning it can cause some minor damage, Finley said. The quake was reported felt as far south as Seattle, 100 miles south of the border, he said. The USGS had received no reports on damage or injuries.

Rescued Satellite Back in Space
DOC.TEXT: An Indonesian communications satellite is back in space 5{ years after shuttle astronauts pulled it from orbit and brought it back to Earth. ``I am very excited. I pray to God'' everything continues to go well, said Makarim Wibisono, press consulate for the Indonesian Embassy in Washington. She witnessed Friday's launch. An unmanned Delta 2 rocket blasted off on time at 6:28 p.m. with the $60 million satellite from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The satellite separated 26 minutes later and, as expected, settled into orbit about 115 miles away. ``It looks like we have a normal vehicle on our hand,'' said Skip Mackey, a NASA test director. An on-board kick motor was to boost the 1,437-pound satellite into its final geosynchronous orbit 22,300 miles above the equator Sunday. The Palapa B-2R satellite was one of two rescued from a uselessly low orbit by the shuttle Discovery in November 1984. The rescue came nine months after the satellites were launched by NASA aboard Challenger. Astronauts Joe Allen and Dale Gardner manually placed the satellites in Discovery's payload bay. The second satellite, originally built for Western Union, was returned to space on a Chinese ``Long March 3'' rocket on April 7. The successful sendoff marked China's debut into the international satellite launching business. The refurbished Indonesian satellite will join two other Palapa satellites already in orbit, electronically linking the 177 million people who live on the country's 13,677 islands. It is expected to go into operation in six weeks. The Indonesian satellites also will be used for internal communications services in the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Papua New Guinea. Hughes Aircraft Co., which built the recovered Palapa, replaced its batteries, on-board thrusters and motors used to boost the satellite into its proper orbit. Damage during its nine months in space was ``amazingly benign,'' said Dave Braverman, a vice president for Hughes. Friday's launch cost $137.5 million, including $50 million for the McDonnell Douglas Commercial rocket and $27.5 million for an insurance premium covering loss of the satellite. The satellite originally was scheduled for launch April 9. The launch was pushed back three days when the National Aeronautics and Space Administration moved up the date of Discovery's launch with the Hubble Space Telescope. The Palapa's launch was delayed yet again _ to Friday _ when Discovery's mission was scrubbed Tuesday. The space agency later said the Discovery mission would be delayed until April 25. The Palapa B-2R is the fourth Palapa satellite to be launched by McDonnell Douglas. It is the Huntington Beach, Calif., company's third commercial launch.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Declare Crop Quarantine in Medfly Area
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture officials declared a quarantine on commercially grown crops on 81 square miles in Riverside County because a Medfly was discovered in an orange tree. The Mediterranean fruit fly was found Thursday in a commercial orange grove in Woodcrest, sparking concerns that the crop-destroying insect has established itself in the agricultural region, state officials said Friday. The officials Friday also announced the discovery of two other Medflies, one in an area of Glendora already sprayed by the pesticide malathion in a controversial program aimed at protecting crops against the insect. The other Medfly was found in suburban Walnut, in an area which has not been sprayed. The discoveries prompted the state's science advisors to call a meeting for Monday to decide how to respond. The Medflies were found less than a month after agricultural officials announced they would try to halt aerial malathion spraying in May and battle the pest with sterile flies. The state Department of Agriculture has been spraying malathion over nearly 400 square miles of suburban Los Angeles and Orange counties to battle an infestation that turned up last summer. Medflies lay eggs in more than 200 fruits and vegetables. The discovery of the Medfly in the Riverside County orange tree was particularly unsettling. The region's navel oranges have already been picked and the area's grapefruits and Valencia oranges won't be picked until mid-summer. But officials worried about the economic impact of a serious infestation. The quarantine is expected to let the fruit be sold within the United States, but some foreign countries, including Japan, may not accept fruit grown in an infested area, officials said. The exact boundaries of the quarantine were to be set Monday. It was not immediately known whether officials would order pesticide spraying in the area. A Medfly had been found in the same community on March 21, but no spraying was ordered. ``Since that is the second fly they've found out there, (pesticide) treatment is a possibility,'' said Medfly project spokeswoman Natalie Bosecker. Many residents have objected to having their homes sprayed at night with malathion from helicopters out of fear the pesticide was unhealthful and the helicopters could crash. State officials have said the pesticide is sprayed in safe, small amounts and have defended the safety record of the company contracted to fly the helicopters.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Witness Accounts of Killings Don't Match
DOC.TEXT: A measure of calm returned to this northern New Jersey community but more discrepancies emerged today between police and witness accounts of the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager by a white police officer. Scores of black college students marched for racial understanding Friday and police continued to arrest individuals suspected of participating in Wednesday's looting and violence stemming from the shooting of Phillip Pannell. Pannell, 16, of nearby River Edge, was shot and killed Tuesday night by Teaneck police officer Gary Spath, who was responding to an anonymous telephone tip that a teen-ager had drawn a gun on another youth. Spath has since been suspended with pay and Officer Wayne Blanco, who responded with Spath, has been temporarily relieved of his duties, acting Bergen County Prosecutor John Holl said. ``Tensions are still high .. it's going to be an emotional weekend,'' said Walter Fields, an official with the Bergen County chapter of the NAACP, as he marched with 200 students along Teaneck Road, where the windows of a dozen businesses were shattered Wednesday night during several hours of looting and violence. ``We don't condone the violence but we do thoroughly understand the anger,'' said Fields. Companions of the slain youth said he had been handling a BB pistol when police approached him and other youths, and that he put it in his coat and ran away with it before police frisked him, The New York Times reported today. An adult witness said Pannell was shot as he lept over a hedge. Police have said Blanco did frisk Pannell and felt in Pannell's coat a heavy object he suspected was a gun. Police also have said they recovered a loaded .22-caliber gun from Pannell. Michelle Ortiz, 15, told the Times that about 20 youths were hanging out in a park before the shooting. ``Phil took a BB gun and was fooling around with it,'' passing it back and forth with another friend, Ms. Ortiz said. She said two police cars screeched to a halt in the park, and one officer jumped out of each car, pointing pistols at the youths and shouting ``Freeze! Get your hands up!'' Police shuffled some of the youths toward a wall, but Pannell ran and police chased him, the Times quoted Jonathon Owen, 15, and Shawn Robinson, 14, as saying in separate interviews. An adult who lives across the street from the shooting scene, Jennifer Bradley, said Pannell was shot as he ran down a driveway. ``I was shouting, `Don't shooot him, don't shoot him.' The second guy, fatter, shot him in the back,'' Bradley said. An autopsy by the Bergen County medical examiner showed Pannell was shot once in the back. Police said an investigation showed that Spath's .38-caliber service revolver had been fired twice, and that Blanco's revolver was not fired. A grand jury is scheduled to begin hearing testimony on the case on Tuesday. A peaceful candlelight vigil Wednesday night in remembrance of the slain youth turned violent as mostly black teen-agers roamed local streets smashing store windows and overturning cars. Five people have been arrested so far.
