That's Hollywood script stuff.'' _ Alvin Young, director of the Agriculture Department's bioltechnology office, after a project supervisor raised the possibility that space-radiated tomato seeds might contain toxic substances.

``We are the dirty-hands people who feed, clothe and shelter this nation.'' _ Evelyn Badger of the Oregon Lands Coalition, a pro-logging industry group that organized a rally in Portland protesting recommendations that Congress ban logging in millions of acres of virgin forest.

``We have a will to be a free people. We have tenacity and we must survive.'' _ Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, pledging his pro-independence republic would not back down despite Soviet threats to begin an economic embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Intra-Christian Fighting Continues, France Urges Aoun to Step Down
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian troops battled with tank cannons in east Beirut today, and a newspaper reported that France was pressing renegade Gen. Michel Aoun to give up his struggle for power. At least three people were wounded in the one-hour flareup on the edge of Ashrafiyeh, a residential district controlled by Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia, police said. The thuds of exploding rounds and staccato bursts of machine-gun fire echoed across Beirut. Both sides blamed the other for the clash. The morning flareup subsided into occasional exchanges of sniper fire an hour later, although no cease-fire agreement was announced. By police count, the showdown between Aoun and Geagea for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has killed 875 people and wounded 2,372 since it broke out Jan. 30. Sixteen cease-fire accords arranged by independent Christian figures have silenced the intra-Christian confrontation for periods ranging from a few hours to several days. Meanwhile, An-Nahar, a respected, independent newspaper, said France was trying to persuade Aoun to renounce any claims to the Christian sector in favor of Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi. The report, quoting unidentified sources, said French Ambassador Rene Ala held a three-hour meeting with Aoun Friday in which he relayed the French advice ``to step down.'' France, which ruled Lebanon until the nation's independence in 1943, is the traditional patron of Lebanon's Christian population. The French effort, the paper said, was coordinated with Saudi Arabia, Morocco and Algeria, the three Arab states that brokered a peace accord last October to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. The accord, worked out by Lebanese legislators at the Saudi resort of Taif, called for the equal distribution of power among Moslems and Christians. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronite Catholics, the largest Christian sect in Lebanon. The sect has dominated the nation's political life since independence. Aoun, the Lebanese army commander at the time, rejected the Taif accord and the Nov. 24 election of Hrawi as President. Aoun held out in the shell-shattered presidential palace in suburban Baabda in the Christian enclave east of Beirut. Hrawi was forced to set up temporary headquarters in Syrian-policed Moslem west Beirut. Hrawi's government, led by Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, has repeatedly referred to Aoun as a ``power usurper.'' Arab League envoy Lakhdar Ibrahimi, currently in Lebanon with new proposals to help Hrawi remove obstacles blocking implementation of the Taif accord, said he will not meet with Aoun. Geagea has recognized Hrawi as head of state and invited his government to take over army camps and government offices in areas of his control in the Christian enclave.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Picks New Central Committee
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's ruling Communist Party has named a new, smaller Central Committee and will remove 80 percent of old committee members from office, China's official Xinhua News Agency said today. Earlier, at an extraordinary four-day congress of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, leaders adopted a new party constitution and platform that reflected the recent acceptance of democratic reforms and opposition parties. The congress ended on Friday. Xinhua said the party's Central Committee was trimmed to 91 members from 146. Delegates said younger, more educated people would comprise much of the committee. The 926 congress delegates also chose a new leadership body, to be renamed the Presidium instead of the current Politburo. But the Presidium was to consist of the same five men appointed to the Politburo less than a month ago after an opposition hunger strike forced out the old party leadership. The chairman of the Presidium, Gombojavyn Ochirbat, 61, was named party chief a month ago amid a leadership shakeup triggered by pro-democracy protests. The Communists have ruled this Soviet-allied pastoral nation with an iron grip since 1921, when the Soviets helped Mongolia gain independence from China. Protests for reform began in December, inspired by Soviet glasnost and the fall of Communist parties in Eastern Europe. On March 23, the parliament abolished the Communist Party's monopoly on power and approved free Parliamentary elections, tentatively scheduled for July. Earlier in the congress, the party, seeking to change its image and maintain control after the elections, dropped the word ``communism'' from its constitution and set a new goal of building ``democratic, human socialism.'' The new party constitution adopted also cuts the number of party employees, gives more financial and decision-making power to local party and guarantees their right to criticize the center. Xinhua said the congress also decided to set up a commission to investigate former high-ranking officials. The opposition has charged former leaders with corruption and persecution of dissidents. The report said the delegates agreed to postpone the party's next congress, scheduled for November, until next year.

DOC.TEXT: Virginio Rotondi, a Jesuit who helped handle the Vatican's postwar relations with the Italian political world and founded an international spiritual movement, died Friday at age 78. The cause of death was not disclosed. Rotondi, who became a priest in 1942, later became a close adviser to Pope Pius XII, for whom he acted as a liaison with politicians during the early years of the Italian republic after World War II. In 1950 he founded Oasis, which spread to 17 countries, including Poland, Brazil and Portugal. For 19 years, he read the Bible and commented on its passages on a national radio program called ``The Most Beautiful Book in the World.'' He was also a regular commentator on a radio show called ``Listen, It's Almost Evening,'' with Rome's chief rabbi, Elio Toaff. Among his books are ``Simple Answers'' and ``30 Conversations With Father Rotondi.''

Luis Trenker, a film maker whose career spanned five decades, died Friday of natural causes at age 97. Trenker made his acting debut in 1921 in Arnold Fanck's ``Marvels of Ski.'' In the early 1930s, Trenker became a film director and writer. His first film was ``Mountains in Flames'' in 1932. One of Trenker's best-known works was ``Il Figlio Perduto'' (The Lost Son) made in 1934 and set in New York. He also made many documentaries.

Janet A. Craig, a retired state health official and aunt of Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, died Wednesday at age 69. Miss Craig was the sister of Marilyn Quayle's mother. She was director of the nursing home license department of the Indiana State Board of Health for 10 years, retiring in 1982.

Cove Hoover, former publisher of newspapers in New York, Illinois and Pennsylvania, died Friday. He was 67. The cause of death was not given. Hoover's newspaper career started in the Boston area at the Patriot-Ledger. He joined the Elmira Advertiser in October 1950. Hoover was named managing editor of the morning Elmira Advertiser in 1953 and managing editor of the Elmira Sunday Telegram in 1955. In 1957, he became managing editor of the afternoon Elmira Star-Gazette, and by Jan. 1, 1959, Hoover was in charge of the news departments at all three Elmira newspapers. He was named general manager in 1965 an was promoted to publisher two years later. The title of president was in May 1970. Gannett Co. Inc., which owns the Elmira Star Gazette, transferred Hoover in 1972 to Rockford, Ill., where he became publisher of the Rockford Morning Star, the Register-Republic and the Sunday Register-Star. Hoover left Gannett in 1975, when he was named editor and publisher of the Delaware County Daily Times in Chester, Pa.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Warns Papers Against Critical Ad
DOC.TEXT: An anti-cholesterol crusader says he'll continue his battle for the good diet, despite McDonald's Corp.'s claim that ads he placed in the nation's newspapers are misleading and malicious. ``We will continue to warn the American public about the dangers of high cholesterol,'' Phil Sokolof, an Omaha industrialist out to change the nation's eating habits, said Friday. Sokolof placed advertisements in newspapers nationwide April 4, asking McDonald's Corp. to lower the amount of saturated fat on its menu. The ads, headlined ``The Poisoning of America!'' included a plea to McDonald's to cut the fat in their hamburgers by 10 percent. But McDonald's said Friday the ad was inaccurate. Attorney Joseph Califano, who represents McDonald's, said letters have been written to newspapers advising them not to publish it again. ``We think the papers just didn't check the facts,'' said Califano, secretary of health, education and welfare in the Carter administration. ``Now they know the facts, now they are all on notice. ... To publish anything like that ad would be a malicious act,'' Califano said. McDonald's said the ad was riddled with error. ``Just about everything in the ad except the spelling of McDonald's was inaccurate,'' said Chuck Ebeling, a spokesman for the Oak Brook, Ill.-based company. Sokolof, reached in Omaha, said McDonald's was putting up a ``smokescreen'' and that the ad was a public service. ``McDonald's has chosen to try and intimidate the nation's leading newspapers,'' said Sokolof, who blames a bad diet for a heart attack he suffered years ago. He would not rule out placing more ads in the future, but would not reveal any specific plans. Ebeling said the ad ``blatantly overstated'' the saturated fat content of McDonald's products, including an assertion that McDonald's precooked hamburger meat is 21.5 percent fat. ``In reality, the fat content before cooking is 17 to 20 percent fat and is typically 19.5 percent fat,'' Ebeling said. An official of a Washington, D.C.-based consumer advocacy group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said either way the saturated fat levels in fast food are too high. ``To me, the important part is that the general thrust of the ad was correct,'' said nutrition director Bonnie Liebman. ``Many of the foods served at McDonald's are loaded with saturated fat and cholesterol and eating less would reduce heart disease _ the nation's largest killer. ``A 10 percent reduction would still leave us with pretty fatty sandwiches, but it's a start,'' she said. Ebeling said McDonald's has worked over the past several years to develop a more healthy menu that now includes salads, 2 percent milk, and bran muffins. The company is also experimenting with using pure vegetable oil _ rather than the current beef shortening-vegetable oil mixture _ for frying its french fries and hash browns.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing to Build New Folding-Wing Jet with Japanese Companies
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co., three years behind competitors in developing a new, mid-size commercial jet, plans to make a folding-wing plane with three Japanese companies as suppliers. The agreement announced Friday lets the Japanese aerospace firms make about one-fifth of the plane's components and share roughly the same proportion of risk without holding an equity position, Boeing officials said. The 353-seat jet would fill a size gap between the Boeing 767 and the Boeing 747 jets, company officials said. It would be larger than the 767 and smaller than the 747. That would put the new airplane, the so-called 767-X, in competition with models made by McDonnell Douglas and the European consortium Airbus Industrie. Both have been developing planes of similar range and size for about three years. The Japanese companies would be contractors for _ not partners in _ the project. But they will be able to capitalize their share of earnings from the new plane, Boeing officials said. ``I think this is the first time we've gone this far. ... But their participation would be limited a great degree over what it would have been if they had been an equity partner,'' said Lawrence W. Clarkson, senior vice president for government and international affairs of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. A memorandum of understanding was signed Thursday between Boeing and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries. A final agreement was expected this summer. Boeing hopes to announce orders for the new plane this year and begin deliveries in 1995. The plane is to be renamed the 777 once in production. Clarkson said the Japanese companies would make 15 percent to 20 percent of the new airframe. He said an equity arrangement with the Japanese is possible on future projects. Estimates that the initial investment to develop the plane would be about $3 billion were ``probably close, within a billion or so,'' Clarkson said. Some trade experts have expressed fear that Japan would use proprietary information as it tries to become an aerospace power. Clarkson said that fear is not valid. ``We're not afraid of the Japanese,'' he said. ``The issue of technology transfer that has been so highly speculated about we believe is not a valid issue.'' The initial model would have a 197-foot wingspan, would be 206 feet long and carry passengers in two classes. It would have a range of 4,600 nautical miles, said Alan R. Mulally, vice president for engineering of Boeing's New Airplane Division. Mulally said the plane is designed to replace the 687 McDonnell Douglas DC-10s and Lockheed L-1011s that will be approaching 25 years of age in the mid-1990s. The wings of the new jet would be able to fold upward about 23 to 25 feet from the tips, letting it use existing airport gates for older models, which have shorter wings. Clarkson said the Japanese would produce about the same components for the new plane as they now do for the 767. Production of wings and other key technologically advanced parts will remain with Boeing, he said.

DOC.HEAD: High School Student Suspended For Notebook Entries Files Suit
DOC.TEXT: A high school sophomore contends in a federal lawsuit that her free-speech rights were violated when she was suspended for allegedly writing menacing and obscene messages in a notebook circulated by students. The notebook contained at least two death threats against teachers and included gruesome references to chopping an administrator into pieces and wishing to castrate a teacher, officials said. Heather Gilbertson, one of four Reno High School students suspended for two days last month, filed the U.S. District Court lawsuit Friday against the Washoe County School District and officials on behalf of herself and other pupils. She said students' constitutional rights to free speech and free expression were abused by school officials in trying to control student writings in the notebook, called ``The Not-So-Sacred Note Flow, Jr.'' The notebook hasn't been made public. The suspensions were ``intended to allow educators to exercise control over student expression and allow educators to police thought and restrict speech in this form,'' said the lawsuit filed by attorney Jack Schroeder of Reno. ``This wasn't a publication; it was a communications system, just like notes being passed between students,'' Schroeder said. ``Some students may have said some strong things about teachers but to my knowledge there was never any follow up or intent to follow up.'' The lawsuit seeks a court order to forbid the school district from continuing to limit student speech by punishing students for writings. Steve Mulvenon, spokesman for the school district, said the students were disciplined because of the nature of the messages. ``The circulation of that notebook had created a climate in the school that the principal thought was not conducive to a good education,'' Mulvenon said. ``The notebook was violent, threatening against teachers and staff and also used language that was offensive and personally invasive.'' Mulvenon said he wasn't surprised by the lawsuit and he welcomes the opportunity to ``see whether what the school district did was within our rights or not.'' The spiral notebook was discovered when a student left it in a classroom and a teacher turned it into Principal Patrick Rogan, who decided the students' punishment. Students have said they didn't mean any harm by the notebook which included a passage explaining what the purpose of the journal. It says, in part, ```The Flow' is a place to voice feelings, read what other people have to say, get and give advice, and communicate on a different level of life. It's a place to reveal your personal insights on anything, and get feedback to what you say.''

DOC.HEAD: Madonna Cheers Fans, Bothers Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: More than 34,000 Japanese fans reveled to the sounds of Madonna as the pop music star opened her second Japan tour, but nearby residents complained of the din. Incessant rain didn't stop fans from pouring into the outdoor Chiba Marine Stadium, 21 miles outside of Tokyo, for the two-hour performance Friday night. Stripping to metallic lingerie, which Japanese newspapers alternately called gold and silver, Madonna sang 18 songs, including longtime hits ``Like a Virgin,'' ``Material Girl'' and ``Holiday.'' Newspapers commented that she even tried to orientalize her hit ``Like a Prayer,'' although they described the rendition as more reminiscent of Chinese, rather than Japanese, music. The tabloid Nikkan Sports said Friday night's performance, the first of nine in Japan, revealed a new Madonna to local fans. ``Although she possessed the same lingerie look as three years ago, the meticulous composition and staging of her performance was completely different.'' Not everyone was pleased with the performance, however. Local police counted about 50 noise complaints from residents living within one to two miles of the new stadium, which opened on March 24. Madonna's first tour to Japan in 1987 also was marred by bad weather. Heavy rains and strong winds on the night of one performance forced her to cancel a concert, causing a stampede by enraged fans. After the concert, 48-year-old office worker Kazunari Igarashi even filed a suit against the singer, asking for $57 in mental damages and a makeup concert. Tokyo District Court rejected the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Says Pakistan Moving Troops
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh said today Pakistan has moved radar units and armored regiments close to the Indian border and is readying its airfields. He said India would be prepared for ``any eventuality'' with Pakistan. Meanwhile, tension was high today in Jammu-Kashmir, the main issue between the countries because of a Moslem separatist movement in the Indian-held portion of Kashmir. Speaking to reporters, Singh said Pakistan had already ``sounded a red alert, which is the last word'' regarding war preparations. Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said there were signs of ``war clouds hanging over the country.'' But in Islamabad, a Foreign Ministry official called the allegations a ``figment of V.P. Singh's imagination'' and said the Indian prime minister's statements proved his country is trying to provoke war. ``India cannot accept the fact that the Kashmiris want their freedom and they are not only trying to oppress this movement but to start another war and blame us,'' the official said on condition of anonymity. Pakistan's prime minister, Benazir Bhutto, has denied charges of aiding separatists but said Pakistan supports the rights of the Kashmiris to self-determination. Today, Ms. Bhutto's archrival said the political opposition would set aside its differences with the government to defend the country against attack by India. ``The present challenge requires us to face it as a united and spirited nation,'' said Nawaz Sharif, the powerful chief minister of Punjab and leader of the right-wing opposition alliance. In Jammu-Kashmir, a grenade thrown by militants exploded near an army truck, injuring three soldiers. Police said the attack occurred outside Srinagar, the troubled Indian state's capital and focus of a Moslem separatist movement. An around-the-clock curfew entered its eighth day in Srinagar. Police arrested 100 people in their search for the killers of three kidnap victims. The bullet-ridden bodies of L.M. Khera, general manager of the Hindustan Machine Tools. Co., Kashmir University Vice Chancellor Mushir Ul-haq and his secretary were found earlier this week. Moslem separatists had demanded the release of three jailed militants in exchange for the men, but the government refused. In Bhaderwah, 125 miles north of the capital, a man wounded in a security forces attack Friday died of bullet injuries this morning. At least 270 people have been killed since the government launched a crackdown on Moslem militants in the state in January. In Srinagar, army vehicles traveled door to door offering food to residents who have been forced to stay indoors since April 7, a day after the kidnappings. But residents in several sections of the city refused the food. They, too, shouted anti-government slogans and called for independence for Kashmir. In the past week police have detained more than 1,000 people, mostly young men and boys, in their search for the kidnappers, security officials said on condition of anonymity. On Friday, Moslem militants kidnapped a former member of the state legislature. Amirullah Khan, 75, was abducted from his home in Shopian, 40 miles northeast of Srinagar. Khan is a member of Gandhi's Congress Party. Kashmir is disputed by India and Pakistan. Since the two countries won independence in 1947 from British colonial rule, India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the region. Kashmir is now divided by a cease-fire line monitored by the United Nations. Moslem separatists in Kashmir say they want an independent country, attached neither to Moslem Pakistan nor India. India's population is 82 percent Hindu, and Jammu-Kashmir state is the only state with a Moslem majority. Moslems account for 64 percent of the state's 6 million people and Hindus make up 34 percent. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 milion people.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Criticized for Transferring Mapplethorpe Case To City Prosecutors
DOC.TEXT: Hamilton County Prosecutor Arthur Ney is trying to deflect criticism for dropping out of the obscenity case against an art gallery showing the late Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photographs. The Contemporary Art Center and its director were indicted one week ago on misdemeanor obscenity charges for displaying seven photos that show naked children or homoerotic acts. Mayor Charles Luken said Friday he thinks Ney sent the case to city prosecutors because he doubted he could win. But Ney said Thursday that his county office is barred by Ohio law from prosecuting misdemeanor cases. ``I think this is a politically hot potato, and the reason Mr. Ney is doing this is that he doesn't feel he can win,'' Luken said. Ney's assistant, Chip Gerhardt, denied that the county prosecutor had withdrawn because he thought he would lose. ``The law is clear on this, and Mr. Luken's a lawyer and he should understand the law,'' Gerhardt said. City Council members Guy Guckenberger and David Mann, both of whom are lawyers, said the city should drop the case if the county refuses to pursue it. ``I have no interest in paying hundreds of thousands of dollars for this litigation,'' Guckenberger said. ``We have much more important priorities in the city.'' A survey published Friday by The Cincinnati Post found that 59 percent of Cincinnati residents support the Arts Center in displaying the photographs, and 38 percent said the show should be prohibited. ``These numbers shatter the myth that this is a heavily conservative community,'' said Al Tuchfarber, director of the University of Cincinnati's Institute for Policy Research, which conducted the survey for the Post. The telephone poll of 561 adults in Hamilton County on Wednesday and Thursday found that 96 percent of those surveyed had heard about or seen the Mapplethorpe exhibit since it opened April 6. The poll's margin of sampling error was 4 percent. About 18,000 people have viewed the 175-photograph exhibit since it opened April 6. A county grand jury indicted the Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, last Saturday on misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. Barrie and the gallery are to be arraigned Monday. If convicted, Barrie could be sentenced to six months in jail on each of the two counts.

DOC.HEAD: Renegade Soldiers Warn Of Attacks Against British `Mercenaries'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with statement warning Washington. Pickup 3rd, `The letter...'
DOC.TEXT: A group of renegade soldiers told the British Embassy today that it would attack alleged British mercenaries training President Corazon Aquino's security guard. Meanwhile, another underground military group said that if the U.S. government continues intervening in Philippine affairs Washington officials may face ``a fight they will never forget.'' The Revolutionary Alliance for the Masses-Soldiers of the Filipino People distributed a statement with the U.S. warning today outside the Philippine Constabulary jail, where leaders of past coup attempts were held. ``The U.S. government will be solely responsible for whatever actions we might consider to take against them,'' the statement said. It referried to U.S. air support for Mrs. Aquino's forces during the Dec. 1-9 failed coup attempt that left more than 113 people dead and over 600 wounded. The warning to the British Embasy by the Young Officers Union, one of several underground right-wing military groups plotting against Mrs. Aquino, came in an open letter. Copies were sent to news agencies. The letter, dated Friday, was signed by Capt. Carlos Maglalang. Military spokesmen said there was no officer in the armed forces by that name. The Soldiers Union said it had identified the alleged British mercenaries and traced where they were staying. It urged the British Embassy to order them out of the Philippines, saying otherwise they would face ``drastic action.'' The group said that on Wednesday and Thursday British military instructors joined troops from Mrs. Aquino's Presidential Security guard in staging mock attacks on the palace, the airport and the House of Representatives building. Horacio Paredes, a spokesman for Mrs. Aquino, confirmed the presidential guard held military exercises on those days but declined comment on whether British nationals were involved. It could not be determined whether the letter had reached the British Embassy because its offices were closed for the four-day Easter holiday. Telephone calls to the embassy went unanswered. ``Our forces in Manila have closely monitored the activities of these mercenaries,'' the letter said, adding they represented ``a direct intervention in the country's internal security affairs and a clear violation of Philippine sovereignty.'' On Wednesday, military officials warned the government about the possibility of new attempts by renegade troops to topple the government. There have been about six right-wing military bids to oust Mrs. Aquino since she took office in a 1986 civilian-military uprising that deposed Ferdinand Marcos.

DOC.HEAD: Attendance, And Controversy, Increase At France's Bullrings
DOC.TEXT: France's bullfight season opened today with both aficionados and critics intensifying lobbying campaigns in advance of expected moves to outlaw the increasingly popular spectacle. The annual number of ``corridas'' _ programs of several bullfights _ has doubled in the past decade to more than 120. Total attendance last year was 600,000, and a national association of fans has been formed to defend bullfighting. Animal protection groups, in turn, have escalated their offensive against bullfighting. They want first to stop its spread, and eventually to ban it. Bullfighting was introduced in France in 1853 at the urging of Empress Eugenie, the Spanish-born wife of Napoleon III. Almost a century later, in 1951, the government enshrined bullfighting in a law that authorizes its continuation in towns where it qualifies as a longstanding local tradition. That effectively limited corridas to southern cities and towns such as Nimes and Arles, where Spanish immigrants have helped kindle a passion for bullfighting. Attendance at French bullfights stagnated in the 1970s but began increasing steadily in the mid-1980s. Attendance in Spain, the world's bullfighting capital, also is rising. A recent survey taken by the French fans' association, the National Association for the Defense of ``l'Aficion,'' indicated that the spectators include large numbers of young people, many with white-collar jobs. Promoters have succeeded in obtaining more media coverage for bullfighting. The country's increasing popular pay-TV network, Canal Plus, now shows highlights of bullfights, and the trendy leftist Parisian daily Liberation devoted an entire page today to the opening of the season. For Rene Berlandier, president of the fans' association, the main problem facing bullfighting is excessively high ticket prices. Even with the influx of younger, better-educated fans, he said the average ticket price of nearly $30 is a burden. According to his group's polls, 33 percent of the fans have less than $1,700 in annual disposable income. The growing popularity of bullfighting distresses France's Society for the Protection of Animals. ``They have created a need in an artificial way,'' said the society's president, Jacqueline Faucher, of the bullfight promoters. ``And they shouldn't talk to me about traditions. In this area, it's the tradition of the cash-register above all.'' She said the society objects to the idea that ``the agony and the death of an animal should become a spectacle.'' ``In the short term we want to ensure that corridas are truly limited to towns where they are traditional, according to the law. In the long term, we are battling for the prohibition, pure and simple, of this barbarity.'' The biggest threat to bullfighting could come from the European Parliament, where deputies seeking to outlaw it may gain broader powers as European integration increases after 1992. Thus far, French aficionados aren't overly worried by the spectre of a ban. According to the survey taken by Berlandier's group, their biggest worry for now is that the bulls are becoming too feeble.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 400 Arrested At Abortion Demonstrations In Philly, California
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 361 protesters during a Good Friday clash at a health center between pro-choice and anti-abortion advocates. And in Southern California on Friday, 48 people were arrested in Tustin when anti-abortion demonstrators blocked a medical clinic during one of a series of Easter weekend protests planned by the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue. The arrests in Philadelphia came during an anti-abortion demonstration at the Elizabeth Blackwell Health Center as more than 500 pro-choice advocates lined the sidewalks in front of the women's clinic to prevent abortion foes from closing the center. It was not clear how many of the people arrested were anti-abortion demonstrators and how many were pro-choice. The demonstrators in Philadelphia were charged with obstructing traffic, which was rerouted. They face fines of up to $300, police said. ``We are allowed to break a law to save a life,'' said Gloria Romana, 48, of Norristown. She said she had been arrested at least 18 times before during anti-abortion protests. The center regularly schedules abortions on Mondays, Fridays and Saturdays. In California, Operation Rescue members clashed with pro-choice advocates at Doctors Family Planning clinic in the Orange County city of Tustin, about 50 miles south of Los Angeles. Tustin Councilman John Kelly, who was defeated for re-election last week and leaves office Tuesday, was among those arrested on a misdemeanor trespassing charge. He is an abortion opponent. The charge is punishable by up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Sends Message to Lithuanian, Meets Top Gorbachev Aide
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II met unexpectedly today with an aide to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, one day after the Soviet president issued an ultimatum to the rebellious Baltic republic of Lithuania. The pontiff also sent an Easter message to Lithuania, saying he felt closer than ever to the aspirations of the Soviet republic's largely Catholic people. A Vatican spokesman, Monsignor Piero Pennacchini, said the private audience, which lasted 30 minutes, was requested by Vadim Zagladin, a special adviser to the Soviet president. ``The visit to His Holiness is part of the contacts that have been taken up again between the Holy See and the Soviet government to deal with problems related to the life of the church in the Soviet Union as well as the problems inherent to international collaboration,'' Pennacchini said. He did not comment further on the meeting or say whether it touched on the crisis in Lithuania, which declared independence from Moscow on March 11. The meeting was not announced until shortly before it took place. A week ago, the Holy See's envoy to Moscow, Archbishop Francesco Colasuonno, said in an interview that the Vatican might be willing to mediate in the dispute over Lithuania if asked to do so. Lithuania's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, said his republic will not bend to Gorbachev's threat to cut off crucial supplies such as oil if the republic does not rescind its strongest independence measures by Sunday. Shortly before Pennacchini's statement, the Vatican released a text of an Easter telegram sent today by the Polish pope to Cardinal Vincentas Skadkevicius of Lithuania. ``In this hour of trepidation and hope, I am particularly near to the Lithuanian church,'' he said. ``My affectionate solicitude embraces likewise all your noble people to whose aspirations I have never been closer, especially in this Easter period,'' the pope said, adding that he prayed that ``may providence support individuals and the people as a whole, the fates of your dear nation.'' The telegram, which ended with an apostolic blessing, was sent in Latin. The Vatican released an Italian translation. The pope has disclosed on two occasions that he had been barred from visiting Lithuania. Gorbachev invited the pope to the Soviet Union when the Soviet president was received by John Paul at the Vatican last year, but the pope has announced no commitment to visit. Lithuania, an independent nation before World War II, was occupied by the Soviet Union in 1940.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Jam Borders For Holiday; Controversy on Monetary Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs at end to UPDATE with former East German defense minister calling for drastic disarmament. TRIMS to tighten. ^By KEVIN COSTELLOE
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Germans from East and West jammed border crossings for Easter weekend trips and the first chance in decades to spend the holiday with relatives on the other side. Meanwhile, officials haggled over the currency exchange rate for a monetary union, one of the first steps toward German unification. East Germany's new government, headed by Lothar de Maiziere, on Thursday eased passport checks to handle the holiday crush. Border guards usually open passports to verify identification, but on Friday they barely glanced at them. On Friday, the traditional start of the long Easter weekend, bumper-to-bumper traffic stretching 40 miles was reported near the West German city of Hanover. At the Helmstedt border crossing, police said traffic was moving slowly and backed up for 30 miles. Many Germans seized their first chance in decades to spend Easter with relatives on the other side. Others took advantage of the long weekend to sightsee for the first time in their neighboring state. Officials said most traffic was heading from west to east. East Germany and East Berlin in general have become tourist meccas since the nation's October revolution ended four decades of communism. West Germany's ARD television reported late Friday that some travelers waited up to four hours to get gas at service stations along routes in East Germany. Meanwhile, East Germany's new finance minister, Walter Romberg, was quoted Friday as saying the West German government must understand East Germans need a 1-to-1 exchange of money in the monetary union planned for July 1. Romberg told West Germany's Die Welt newspaper that he could foresee initially limiting the equal exchange to salaries and retirement pay, and for savings accounts up to 7,000 marks. Die Welt quoted Romberg as saying an equal exchange for larger amounts could be delayed until East Germany's economy is in better shape. At a 1-to-1 exchange, 7,000 East German marks would be worth $4,100. At the current exchange, the amount is worth about $1,370. Average salaries in East Germany are about 1,000 marks a month, now worth $196. Retirement pay is about one-half that sum. Officials of West Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, have proposed a 1-to-1 exchange rate for savings accounts up to 2,000 East German marks, or $1,175. The Bundesbank would make the rate two East German marks for one West German mark in other cases. In another development, West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, called for a quick meeting with Markus Meckel, East Germany's new foreign minister, to prepare a united position for international talks on unification. The coming talks will include the two German states and the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ the World War II Allies who defeated Adolf Hitler's Nazi Germany. A government newspaper in East Germany today quoted that country's former defense minister, Theodor Hoffman, as saying the military in both Germanys should ``set the pace to ease tensions with drastic disarmament.'' He did not elaborate. ``This would contribute to the peoples of Europe having no grounds to fear German military might,'' the newspaper Neues Deutschland quoted him as saying. West Germany has 400,000 soldiers and East Germany 180,000, officials say.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Papers Denounce Court Ruling on Rushdie
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian newspaper said today that a British court decision not to try Salman Rushdie, author of ``The Satanic Verses,'' for blasphemy will block an improvement in British-Iranian relations. The Persian-language daily, Jumhuri Islami, or Islamic Republic, said Britain should realize there will be no flexibility from Iran for improvement of ties unless Britain meets ``the demands of Moslems.'' It said that by neglecting Moslems' complaints, the British tribunal showed it was a ``kangaroo court.'' A British High Court last week rejected a bid by a Moslem group to prosecute Rushdie and publishers Viking Penguin for blasphemy, upholding a lower court decision that Britain's blasphemy laws apply only to the Christian religion. ``More than 1 billion Moslems are enraged with the publication of the blasphemous novel,'' the Iranian newspaper said. ``The fascist government of Britain is once again making faces at Moslems and displaying its hostility against Islam.'' The English daily ``Kayhan International'' said today that Rushdie is ``no more than a moving corpse,'' adding: ``His fate is but certain death _ a fact that the British rulers have to accept sooner or later.'' The late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called on Moslems to kill Rushdie, a British citizen born of an Indian Moslem family. The death sentence was confirmed by Iranian leaders after Khomeini's death in June. Excerpts of today's editorials were carried by the Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Small Plane Crash in France
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD details, CORRECTS hometown in final graf.
DOC.TEXT: A small plane crashed near the Normandy coast, killing all four people aboard and raining wreckage on a town, authorities said today. The single-engine Beechcraft was en route from Britain to Spain, where the four were to vacation, when it went down Friday in Bayeux, 18 miles northwest of Caen, officials said. Witnesses said they heard an explosion, then saw debris falling from the sky. Officials said debris was scattered in residential areas and one body landed on a parked car. ``The fuselage fell less than 10 meters (yards) from a house and about 100 meters from three service stations,'' one firefighter said. No injuries were reported on the ground. The cause of the crash was under investigation. The British pilot, 24-year-old Mark Lilley, died of his injuries at a university hospital in Caen, said officials who by custom do not identify themselves. The others, who died immediately, were identified as his parents, Carolyn Lilley, 45, and Norman Lilley, 46, of Ampleforth in York, and Mary Wilson, whose age and residence were unknown.

DOC.HEAD: Delivery Truck Overturns With 35 Hitchhikers Aboard; Eight Dead
DOC.TEXT: A delivery truck loaded with soft drinks and about 35 hitchhikers lost its brakes and overturned Saturday, killing at least eight people, a survivor and hospital authorities reported. Most of those killed were crushed to death by the cases of soft drinks and many of the injured suffered cuts caused by broken bottles, authorities said. At least 27 people were injured, including the two delivery personnel. One of the deliverers, Joselito Ibahay, said the truck was delivering cases of Coca-Cola to Marawi City when the accident happened near the town of Pantar in southern Lanao del Norte province. Pantar is about 10 miles south of Iligan and about 510 miles southeast of Manila.

DOC.HEAD: One U.S. Soldier Killed, Another Injured In Traffic Accident
DOC.TEXT: A single-car accident killed a U.S. Army soldier and critically injured another, American military officials said Saturday. The officials said the accident happened at Tagwon south of Seoul shortly before noon Friday but gave no other details. The driver of the car was pronounced dead at the scene and the other soldier remained in critical condition at a hospital in Seoul, they said. Both soldiers were assigned to Company N, 702nd Main Support Battalion of the 2nd U.S. Infantry Division, the officials said. Their names were withheld pending notification of the next of kin. U.S. and South Korean officials were conducting an investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Year of Repression Stills Political Oppositon
DOC.TEXT: The anger and hope that burst forth when Hu Yaobang died a year ago are muted now, stilled by a campaign of political repression that seems only to intensify. Security has been tightened to prevent demonstrations marking the April 15, 1989, death of the former Communist Party chief, a popular reformer whose passing inspired a campaign for democratic reform that ended in tragedy. Within hours of Hu's death, posters went up at Beijing University and other campuses praising the leader who was purged in 1987 for not crushing student demonstrations. One said: ``Sincere men have died while hypocrites live on. Is there any hope left for our country?'' Thousands of students soon were marching on Tiananmen Square, ostensibly to mourn Hu but also to decry with growing vehemence the arrogance and corruption of one-party rule. As the weeks went on, factory workers, teachers, journalists and even party members and police joined the peaceful, festive marches for a more democratic government. On May 20, after Chinese leaders were humiliated by the student occupation of Tiananmen Square during a visit by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, martial law was declared in Beijing. China's aging leadership, intimidated by the masses they claimed to represent, declared that a plot was afoot against the party and communism. Tens of thousands of Beijing residents filled the streets to protect the students in the square. Soldiers of the People's Liberation Army smashed through the barricades June 3-4 and shot their way to Tiananmen. Hundreds of people, perhaps thousands, were killed. A year after the movement began, thousands of political activists languish in Chinese jails, uncharged and without access to legal advice. Numbing political indoctrination, a throwback to the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution, continues unabated in schools and workplaces. Zhao Ziyang, purged as party chief in June for pro-student leanings, remains under house arrest. Astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, China's best-known dissident, is a fugitive in the U.S. Embassy. For the many Chinese who still sympathize with the democracy movement's goals, and for the government they oppose, the common denominator is fear. Students are frightened by threats of expulsion from school or arrest if they demonstrate. One student said: ``If something happens, people say they will join in, but no one is willing to take the first step.'' Authorities claim the social situation is stable, but worry that reforms in Eastern Europe will come to haunt China. They have told young people to stay away from Tiananmen Square. Police closed the square to the public April 1 and again on April 5, a festival day on which the Chinese traditionally honor their dead. Overseas dissidents had urged people to stroll across Tiananmen on those days to mourn the victims of the military crackdown. Martial law was lifted in January, but more than 1,000 soldiers are posted in the history museum on the east side of Tiananmen. They march across the square each day chanting praise to socialism, a warning that protests will not be tolerated in the square, China's symbolic political center. ``We absolutely won't allow'' any repetition of last year's protests, said Chen Xitong, the hard-line mayor of Beijing. Although some Western economic sanctions imposed after the crackdown have been lifted, China's relations with the outside world still are marked by suspicion and xenophobia. Premier Li Peng has begun a campaign to teach children about the 1840 Opium War between Britain and China ``so as to heighten their vigilance against the imperialistic strategy'' of turning China into a capitalist state. China insists its doors to the world remain open, and welcomes foreign investment, but the people are told not to talk to foreign journalists. A student's university told him that, if he did not stop seeing his German girlfriend, he would be sent to a job in the remote countryside. Ying Ruocheng, a well-known actor and who is vice minister of culture, admitted some in the hierarchy favor a return to isolation and link politically suspect art to the spread of Western ideas, but said: ``We do not advocate this.'' The democracy movement had a bright moment this month when Chai Ling, a leader of the Tiananmen protests, turned up in France with her husband after 10 months on the run inside China. Both are wanted for counterrevolutionary crimes. Yan Jiaqi, a dissident political scientist who leads the Federation for Democracy in China, based in Paris, said tight political controls make it unlikely any opposition to the government will be evident this spring. Police know the Chinese fondness for anniversaries and will be especially vigilant April 27, the anniversary of one of the biggest demonstrations, and May 4, when a historic student movement in 1919 is observed. Then comes May 20, the day martial law was declared, and finally June 3-4, when the army moved in. For the many Beijing residents who scorn the government but are uneasy about social unrest, it's a matter of enduring the propaganda and the police. ``Everyone tries to avoid talking about politics,'' a young businessman said. ``It can only get you in trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Flies Supplies To Flooded Towns
DOC.TEXT: The air force on Saturday flew emergency Easter supplies to two small outback towns cut off by two weeks of heavy rain in southwest Queensland state, where flood warnings were posted for seven rivers. Overflowing rivers isolated the towns of Quilpie and Thargomindah, both about 670 miles west of Brisbane, police said. For two weeks, all supplies have had to be either flown into the towns or ferried across the swollen rivers. Police at Quilpie said the air force had flown 15 tons of food supplies to the town using Hercules transport planes. Both Quilpie, an opal mining town with a population of 700, and Thargomindah, a small farming community, had more rain Friday night, keeping the rivers high but not causing any serious flooding in the towns themselves, police said. Flood warnings were posted for the Balonne, Maranoa, Paroo, Bulloo, Warrego, Thomson and Barcoo Rivers.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Bus Shootings Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The bus...', to restore dropped first reference to company spokesman Kevin Fry.
DOC.TEXT: Two more shootings at Greyhound buses were reported to federal and state authorities today but the strike-plagued company says no injuries were reported. A bullet ricocheted off a San Antonio-bound bus at a Dallas-area freeway interchange shortly before midnight. Another gunshot struck a bus traveling from Birmingham, Ala., to Nashville, Tenn., a Greyhound spokesman said. Greyhound Lines Inc. has decried the violence, which includes more than 30 shooting attacks, saying the company won't negotiate with striking drivers and other employees until a week goes by without incident. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions in Washington, D.C., also has condemned the violence. A representative of the union did not immediately return telephone calls today from The Associated Press regarding the latest shootings. The Texas bus was carrying no passengers when its driver heard a noise at the interchange with Interstates 35 and 635 in the Dallas suburb of DeSoto. He noticed the damage at Troy, between Waco and Temple, and called the company. The bus was sent on to San Antonio, where it was met by police and an agent of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said Kevin Fry, a Greyhound spokesman in Dallas. The bullet, which struck the bus about 6 feet off the ground near an American flag painted on its right side, was from a small-to midcaliber handgun fired from behind the bus, investigators said. ``It ricocheted off the bus, never penetrating the skin,'' Fry said. The second shooting occurred on a Nashville-bound bus with six passengers aboard. Its driver was at an undetermined location on Interstate 65 when gunfire hit the eastbound bus about 3:20 a.m. CDT today. ATF and FBI agents were investigating the shooting with state and local authorities, Fry said. Both federal agencies did not immediately return calls. On Friday, authorities in Maywood, Ill., discovered a Greyhound bus parked near railroad tracks, its engine still running. It apparently was abandoned after a failed attempt to park it across the tracks, officers said. Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers walked out in March over wages and job security. The company has been operating a reduced schedule since, using permanent replacements and drivers willing to cross picket lines. Besides the shooting attacks on buses, Greyhound has reported 70 bomb threats and more than 100 other incidents of violence. Greyhound's unions have also reported violence directed at them. A picketing driver, Robert Waterhouse, 59, died when he was crushed by a bus driven by a replacement driver in Redding, Calif.; the driver was not charged.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Slowly Ends Hibernation
DOC.TEXT: The sleepy 101st Congress finally is threatening to pass some bills. Usually by now the congressional agenda is clogged with budget resolutions, spending bills, and bins of social legislation. Not this year. The Easter recess was stretched from one week to two as the congressional leadership took advantage of the paucity of pressing business. When they return this Wednesday, the two chambers still have little planned. The House has three minor bills scheduled for action before it adjourns Thursday for another long weekend. The Senate schedule is less certain but equally light. ``This is the easiest Congress I've ever had,'' said one top Senate staffer who's spent more than two decades on Capitol Hill. The Democratic leadership has decided to focus its efforts on a couple of showpiece bills, child care and clean air. The House and Senate have passed competing blueprints for how the government should subsidize child care, and are working toward a compromise that can go to President Bush. The last time a Democratic Congress sent such legislation to a Republican president was in 1971, and President Nixon vetoed it. It's been nearly a decade and a half since the country's clean air laws were significantly updated, but the Senate now has passed a bill with bipartisan support. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., has promised action in his chamber by early May _ and then another House-Senate negotiation will ensue. Campaign finance reform is on the agenda in both chambers, although partisan disagreements may doom enactment. There's talk of compromise in the Senate, but talks in the House between Foley and Minority Leader Robert H. Michel, R-Ill., have come to naught. Most of the remainder of the congressional agenda is bundled up in budget matters and, so far, it's a bottleneck. Halfway through the spending year, Congress and the president are still tinkering with fiscal 1990 spending. Bush asked Congress for an emergency increase of $870 million in foreign aid spending. Most of that would go toward rebuilding Panama after the U.S. invasion and to support Nicaragua's new democratic government. The House passed the bill before the Easter recess, but not before pumping the total up to $2.4 billion with money for food stamps, forest-fire fighting, veterans programs and other domestic spending. The Senate Appropriations Committee is expected to consider its version late this week. Congress was supposed to have completed the fiscal 1991 budget by April 15. But budget resolutions still haven't been voted out of the House or Senate budget committees. Members of both panels have been meeting behind closed doors in recent weeks in attempts to hammer out $1.2 trillion budgets for the new fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. Majority Democrats on each committee are looking for mixtures of minor tax increases and cuts in defense and domestic spending that will yield at least $37 billion in savings, the minimum required by the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law. Republicans have been balking, saying they will stand by the budget President Bush requested in January. Congress faces difficult decisions that will include the depth and character of cuts to be made in military spending and how to squeeze billions of dollars worth of domestic initiatives into an already tight budget. Just like last year, Congress will also have to decide which taxes can be raised while still allowing President Bush to claim adherence to his ``no new taxes'' pledge. Speaker Foley has said that one thing sure to come out of the budget process this year is to move the Social Security trust fund ``off-budget.'' Although just a bookkeeping change, this will give politicians a chance to reassure retired and soon-to-be retired voters that their checks will keep coming. The Democrats continue to blame the slow pace of congressional activity on last year's traumatic removal of former House Speaker Jim Wright, who was accused of violating House ethics rules. Normally in a two-year Congress, the first year is when the groundwork is laid for final passage of legislation in the second year. But ``last year was restoring the civility,'' leaving more of the groundwork for this year, said Jeff Biggs, Foley's spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Canton Judge Warns of Arms Proliferation, Nine Executed
DOC.TEXT: Canton executed three people last week who were convicted of committing crimes with guns and a court sentenced eight others to death in an effort to crack down on illegal firearms in the southern city. Chinese are not allowed to keep guns, with the exception of a few people who hunt in the countryside, and crimes committed by armed assailants are still relatively rare in China. Deng Guoji, chief of Canton's Intermediate Court, said Thursday the selling and buying of illegal guns has become rampant in Canton and that such crimes will be dealt with ``heavily and quickly.'' The report, carried in Canton's Yancheng Evening News on Friday and seen in Beijing on Saturday, quoted Deng as saying criminals were using guns to steal, rape, kill and commit highway robbery. Such armed criminals were ``swollen with arrogance and malicious in the extreme,'' he said. On Thursday, a Canton court sentenced 16 people for crimes involving the use of guns. Of those, three were immediately executed and eight were given the death sentence. The three condemned people were convicted of armed robbery and rape and the murder of a policeman who tried to arrest them. The report said six other people were executed Thursday, including a policeman, for robbery and other crimes. But it was not immediately clear when the six were sentenced or for what crimes. The report said that in 1988 and 1989 Canton police broke more than 30 cases concerning the illegal selling and buying of guns and ammunition. They confiscated about 100 military-use handguns or their copies. Chinese sentenced to death can appeal to a higher court, but few are successful. Executions are carried out with a bullet to the back of the head.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged With Six of Seven Strangulation Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A 22-year-old man with no criminal record has been charged with the murders of six of seven black women found strangled in Kansas City since September. Ray Shawn Jackson, 22, described as a part-time laborer, also was charged with the assault of another woman Monday night whose attack was interrupted by a passerby, authorities said. Jackson was arrested Thursday afternoon at his grandmother's house three blocks east of Gillham Park, where four of the six women were found. He was charged Friday with six counts of first-degree murder, hours after the funeral of the latest victim, Michelle Mitchell. Police Chief Larry Joiner said that the six victims had all been lured to areas in or near the park by the promise of obtaining crack cocaine. The investigation has not produced evidence linking Jackson to the death of a seventh woman, Brenda McCoy, 33, who was found Sept. 26, Joiner said. Many blacks have said authorities and the media failed to give the case adequate attention because the victims were black prostitutes and drug addicts. Joiner said Jackson, who also is black, had no history of violence or any prior arrest record, but it was his understanding he had used drugs. ``I don't think I can get into his motives,'' the police chief said. A woman who told the police she had been with Miss Mitchell and Jackson hours before her body was found helped authorities draw a composite sketch of the suspect. A 27-year-old black woman assaulted on Monday had identified Jackson from a photograph as her assailant, Joiner said. She said the assailant was scared away by a man out walking his dog. Homicide detectives found Jackson while canvassing a neighborhood near the park looking for anyone who recognized the composite drawing. Witnesses pointed police to his grandmother's home and he was arrested when he came home later in the afternoon. In addition to the killing of Miss Mitchell, whose body was found in the park on April 5, Jackson is charged with killing Annette Stewart, 33, found dead on Sept. 16; Kimberly Creer, 22, found Sept. 20; Tresa Williams, 21, found Oct. 22; Janice Berryman, 36, found Oct. 28; and Tonya Ward, 23, found Jan. 18. Jackson's bond was set at $700,000. He was being held in the city jail Friday night, pending an arraignment this morning.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Step Up Aid to Kabul Government, Envoy Says
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has stepped up aid to Afghanistan's government while edging forward in talks for a political end to the 12-year-old war, a senior U.S. diplomat said Saturday. Moscow spends $500 million a month on arms and aid to its allies in Kabul, up from a previous high of $300 million, said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The regime is divided and weak and totally dependent on the Soviet Union, just like us in Vietnam. The Soviet Union is sending $5 billion a year in military and humanitarian aid to Kabul,'' he said. The Moslem guerrillas, known as mujahedeen or Islamic holy warriors, get $600 million annually in military assistance from the United States. They also receive aid from Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and other sympathetic Arab states. The Moslem insurgents have been fighting for 12 years to unseat Afghanistan's Communist-style government and establish an Islamic republic. The Kremlin sent Red Army troops into the Central Asian nation in 1979 to bolster the Kabul government and to put down the burgeoning Moslem insurgency. The Soviet Union pulled out its troops in February 1989, but the U.S. diplomat said 500 Soviet military intelligence officers were operating in the Afghan capital, up from 300 last year. Moscow beefed up its weapons and food supplies to Kabul in December after President Najib uncovered a coup plot, the diplomat said. But less then three months later, Najib's renegade defense minister, Shah Nawaz Tanai, launched the bloodiest and most serious challenge yet. Western diplomats said the March 6 coup weakened Najib, and the diplomat predicted it would push Moscow toward a more flexible bargaining position. ``We're making progress with the Soviets. There is movement (and) there will be more in the months ahead,'' he said, referring to next month's summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. So far, Moscow has refused to open talks on what Washington insists is the key to a settlement _ the removal of Najib. ``Soviets are still insisting on Najib,'' the diplomat said. ``The key is the transfer of power, of police, intelligence, and military to some neutral body. There won't be a political solution as long as Najib and his cohorts are there.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Fight, France Reportedly Tries To Get Aoun To Resign
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled with tank cannon, mortars and machine guns in east Beirut Saturday as France was reported to be trying to persuade Gen. Michel Aoun to step down. At least seven people were wounded in a one-hour battle along the edges of the hilltop residential district of Ashrafiyeh, a stronghold of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. Aoun's 19,000 troops and Geagea's militia have fought each other to a standstill since Jan. 30, killing 875 people and wounding 2,376 in a battle for dominance of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The inconclusive showdown has inflicted property damage estimated at $1 billion and forced about 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million people to flee to safer areas in Lebanon and neighboring states. The two sides blamed each other for Saturday morning's flareup, which coincided with talks in Lebanon by Arab League envoy Lakhdar Ibrahimi in an effort to salvage a peace pact reached more than five months ago. The accord aimed at ending the 15-year-old civil war was worked out by Lebanese legislators at the Saudi resort of Taif last October. Aoun has rejected the Taif accord and the election of Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi a month later. He has criticized the accord for failing to provide a timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. ``The Taif accord has stumbled in the first steps, but there is a real chance to put it on the proper track once again,'' Ibrahimi told reporters after a one-hour meeting with Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronites, the largest Christian sect, which has dominated Lebanon's politics since independence from France in 1943. The prestigious newspaper An-Nahar said that France, traditional patron of Lebanon's Christians, has launched an effort to persuade Aoun to resign in favor of Hrawi. The report, which quoted unidentified informed sources, said French Ambassador Rene Ala held a three-hour meeting with Aoun Friday in which he relayed the French advice. The French effort, the newspaper said, was ``coordinated'' with Saudi Arabia, Morocco and Algeria, whose leaders brokered the Taif accord. A duty officer at the French Foreign Ministry in Paris said there was no one available to comment on the newspaper report.

DOC.HEAD: Publicity War in Greyhound Strike Marks Trend in Labor Disputes
DOC.TEXT: Hours after a sniper opened fire on a Greyhound bus in Florida last month, company chairman Fred Currey was on the scene, boarding a bus to ride under the very overpass where the gunman had hidden. Currey's visit was part of what a company spokesman termed a ``Florida blitz'' designed to gain Greyhound favorable statewide news coverage in the early days of the strike by its drivers' union. ``Every news person in northern Florida was there,'' said Greyhound spokesman George Gravley, whose company dispatched Currey to three Florida cities that day to meet publicly with riders and replacement drivers. Greyhound's public relations gambit was just one battle in the war to court public favor in the six-week-old drivers' strike, but analysts say it reflects a growing trend toward sophisticated publicity contests in labor-management disputes. ``A public relation agent is a participant now either at the bargaining table or right outside the room,'' said Don Blohowiak, a New York media analyst who studies business-media relations. ``The court of public opinion is very important to success in the marketplace. In something like a labor dispute, our impressions stay with us for a very long time,'' Blohowiak said. He said most consumers ``want to do business with companies we like or feel good about, companies we think conduct business with their employees in a reasonable and ethical way.'' Greyhound is not alone in seeking public favor in the strike. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, without an in-house public relations department, hired a Washington company six days before the strike to dramatize the economic issues, such as the decline in drivers' average pay from $31,000 to $21,000 since 1983. Still, some labor leaders complain privately that the union hasn't been as aggressive as Greyhound in seeking to mold public opinion. ``The union hasn't awakened to the fact that it needs to sell its message to win,'' said one labor analyst, speaking on condition of anonymity. But the union's public relations agent, Nick Nichols, said striking drivers can't compete with the company's money. ``Clearly, it's a David and Goliath thing. The Greyhound drivers simply don't have the resources,'' Nichols said. Neither side in the bus strike will say what it's spending for public relations advice. Since March 2, when 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenance and other workers walked out, the strike has been marred by vandalism and violence. The company has refused to return to the bargaining table until a week goes by without a violent incident. Analysts point to the ongoing Eastern Air Lines walkout and last year's Pittston coal strike as recent labor disputes where unions waged successful campaigns to win public support. Although machinists at Eastern are still on strike, their publicity campaign against Frank Lorenzo, head of the carrier's parent company, ``made him out to be the Darth Vader'' of the corporate world in the public's mind, one labor official said. Blohowiak said companies are more media-conscious now than they were 10 years ago because increased competition has prompted consumers to consider a company's attitude toward its workers when making purchasing decisions. ``After seeing the drubbing that Exxon took over one accident, or a Frank Lorenzo took, you can't hide and pretend you don't have problems, that no one's interested,'' he said. Greyhound's efforts to win public opinion have been persistent. Twice in two weeks, Dallas-based Greyhound executives flew to Washington for news conferences to complain about strike-related violence. Neither event had a Washington focus, and in fact, the latest one was to announce the filing of a lawsuit in Florida against union officials. Gravley, the Greyhound spokesman, said the event was held in Washington because that's where the national press corps is based. ``If you want to be heard nationally, you have to go where the national media is,'' said media analyst Don Kellermann. Greyhound used a well-known New York public relations firm, Ruder Finn, for advice and help in setting up the Washington news conferences. It also has taken out several full-page newspaper ads on the strike. Labor officials contend the company's Washington announcements are part of a strategy to distort public perception of the strike. ``It's a great tack for diverting attention from what the real issues are,'' said Denise Mitchell, a Washington public relations agent who helped Pittston miners win widespread community support during last year's coal strike. Sophisticated publicity efforts by management have forced unions to try to keep up, she said. ``We increasingly counsel people that they have to get out front in the contest to win public support,'' Mitchell said. ``Being prepared at the bargaining table, doing your homework on the economic issues, just isn't enough anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS for 1st item in rdp to CORRECT in 4th graf that daughter in another car, sted in car with Ms. Roberson.
DOC.TEXT: A policeman who stopped a car for an expired inspection sticker didn't realize he was about to write up none other than Peter Cottontail. It was really Sondra Roberson, dressed as the bunny of hippity-hoppity fame because she was en route to deliver a basket of balloons for a church Easter party Thursday. ``It was a surprise when the rabbit got out,'' said policeman Gary L. Burnes. ``We joked about it a little bit and I wrote the rabbit a warning ticket.'' ``We thought it was so cute,'' said Ms. Roberson's daughter, Becky Greer, who was going to the party in a second car. ``I guess it's not every day that a Bossier City police officer writes Peter Cottontail a ticket. ``He said he would hate to go home and tell his kids that he had to arrest the Easter Bunny.'' Since getting the warning Thursday, Ms. Roberson said, she had her car inspected and got a new sticker.

DOC.HEAD: US, British Leaders Caution Gorbachev on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf pvs, bgng: He told ..., to UPDATE with Baker comments. Picks up 5th graf, Bush and ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is telling Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that his threatened use of economic sanctions against the independence movement in Lithuania ``is not the way to go.'' Bush said today that he had no further information on the situation in Lithuania or Gorbachev's ultimatum. ``I haven't heard anything about anything this morning,'' he said as he prepared to tee off for golf. ``I haven't seen the intelligence yet. I will when I get in.'' He told reporters that he wanted to get a clarification Friday night, but it was ``midnight over there, early morning.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the administration was taking a ``wait and see'' attitude as it weighed its options in the event of a Soviet economic crackdown. ``It's not entirely easy to know what the next moves are going to be,'' Baker said in an interview on Cable News Network. He said the sanctions ``would have an adverse impact'' on U.S.-Soviet relations. He would not speculate on what the United States response would be to sanctions. Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, meeting Friday on this Atlantic resort island, had issued a joint plea to Gorbachev to settle the Baltic dispute through negotiation rather than coercion. Asked about his daylong meeting with the prime minister, Bush said today, ``It's very important to stay on the same wavelength with Mrs. Thatcher. There are slight nuances on one or two things but we're very close together.'' He refused to elaborate. High winds and a steady rain did not deter Bush from a morning golf game with top aides as well as Thatcher's husband, Denis. Asked why he was playing in such weather, Bush said, ``We wanted the press to walk around and get into shape.'' He said golf ``refurbishes the spirit ... you've got to have a mix of work and recreation.'' The weather cleared by mid-morning and when Bush completed his tour of the course at the Mid Ocean Golf Club he was plainly pleased. ``It was just heaven,'' he said of his game. The Soviet news agency Tass reported Friday that Gorbachev had given Lithuania 24 hours to end its ``anticonstitutional acitivities.'' The issue dominated the joint news conference between Bush and Mrs. Thatcher. ``Now is no time for escalation,'' Bush said Friday at a joint news conference with Mrs. Thatcher. He said the United States has made it clear to Gorbachev both publicly and privately that ``coercion, escalation is not the way to go. The way to go is dialogue.'' And he called on the Soviet leader to heed his words. Similarly, Mrs. Thatcher said the confrontation ``must be solved by discussion.'' The president was notified about Gorbachev's ultimatum toward the end of his daylong meeting with Mrs. Thatcher. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said later that the United States was still trying to sort out ``what had happened and what it means.'' Mrs. Thatcher invited Bush to this British colony as a prelude to his Washington summit with Gorbachev late next month. The president met Tuesday with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney in Toronto and will confer with French President Francois Mitterrand in Key Largo, Fla., next week. Friday's talks centered on the prospects of a unified Germany, the future of the NATO alliance and the unrest in the Soviet Union. Both leaders reported a broad measure of agreement on the issues before them. They took time off from their four hours of talks to watch 20 children fly colorful, handmade kites in a traditional Good Friday celebration. They also planted palm trees in a grove where two of their predecessors had done the same. The two leaders and their top aides later mingled at a black-tie reception aboard a British warship, HMS Arrow, and at a dinner. Asked if he would telephone Gorbachev with his concerns about Lithuania, Bush said: ``I might and I might not. But certainly it's time to stay in close contact, and we have many ways of doing that.'' He noted that 24 hours earlier the tone coming from the Soviet Union was quite different. Bush welcomed as a ``positive statement'' Gorbachev's remark to a delegation of U.S. senators that an arms control agreement might be ready in time for their five-day summit, beginning May 30. He said that was a ``different slant'' than the one that emerged from his meeting last week with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Bush said he and Mrs. Thatcher agreed that a unified Germany must remain a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including its military structures. He said this was in the ``genuine security interest of all European states.'' Among the Western allies, Mrs. Thatcher has been portrayed as the one most reluctant to see German unification and favoring a go-slow approach. The prime minister said she and Bush agreed that NATO will continue to need a mix of conventional and nuclear forces and that they must be kept up to date. ``Whether we can make further reductions in the overall number of NATO warheads in Europe is something which will need to be considered as a whole,'' she said. On other issues: _Bush said he would cooperate with any attempts to totally ban the shipment of weapons to terrorist nations. Mrs. Thatcher said British experts were still trying to determine wether a piece of steel piping confiscated before shipment to Iraq was part of an artillery cannon. _Both leaders reiterated their commitment to bring to justice the terrorists who bombed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988. All 259 people on the plane and 11 on the ground were killed. Their statement came in response to a plea from relatives of two victims that the leaders reaffirm their commitment to combat terrorism. Earlier, Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One that he is personally inclined to grant East Germany's request for forgiveness over its rol in the Nazi Holocaust that killed millions of Jews and others. ``I'm a Christian,'' he said, ``and I think that forgiveness is something that I feel very strongly about.'' But he added that the world should not forget the Holocaust. ``You learn from history, what not to do wrong, how to conduct oneself,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Envisions Cutting Quarter of Its Troops Amid Budget Crunch
DOC.TEXT: Top Army officials, pressured to meet demands for sharp reductions in Pentagon spending, have agreed to a proposal that would cut about one soldier in four from the service by 1997, senior Pentagon sources say. Army Secretary Michael Stone and Army Chief of Staff Gen. Carl Vuono gave their final approval to the proposal on Wednesday, said the sources, who spoke on condition of not being identified by name. Under the proposal, active duty forces would plummet from the current 764,000 to 580,000 by the beginning of fiscal year 1997. The number of National Guard and Reserve forces would be slashed as well, although not as precipitously, dropping from the present 776,000 to 645,000 slots over the same time period, the sources said. Even though the move cuts tens of thousands of soldiers from Army rolls _ beyond what the service projected it would do in the last Pentagon budget _ the proposal may not placate demands on Capitol Hill for even more severe layoffs. In hot pursuit of a so-called peace dividend amid lessened superpower tension, some lawmakers have called for cutbacks or even outright cancellation of high-cost weapons programs, such as the $530 million B-2 stealth bomber. But savings can't be gleaned as quickly from long-term weapons programs as they can from personnel accounts because weaponry costs are stretched over a period of many years. So that leaves the manpower-intensive Army, with the largest segment of the nation's 2.1 million-member military force, as the biggest target for possible budget savings. ``It's painful,'' said one senior Pentagon planner who is knowledgeable about the Army's proposal. ``It took some gut-wrenching decisions. But at least we have a plan.'' Another source, who also spoke privately, said the proposal was forced upon the service by ``fiscal reality,'' even as he expressed concerns about pressures to go beyond the 580,000 level. ``That would bring us pretty close to a dysfunctional Army,'' he said, given the national security requirement for a ``trained and ready'' force. The senior official did not say how much savings were being projected from the manpower cut.
