He said a decision had yet to be reached on whether the complaint would seek reinstatement with back pay or damages or both. The newspaper, with a circulation of about 5,000, lost 30 subscribers as a result of the dismissals and three small businesses had canceled advertising, Nierling said earlier. But the paper was ``getting incredible support from the community,'' she said. Since it was founded by Whitehead in his basement in Manassas, Va., in 1982, the institute has grown to 25 state chapters and has an annual budget of about $800,000, said Michael Patrick, the executive director. The institute now makes its home at Charlottesville, Va. Last year, the institute defended a Milwaukee Journal receptionist who was fired over anti-abortion activities. The paper later said that the decision to apply its ethics code to a receptionist was an error. The non-profit organization's 40 staff attorneys handled more than 100 cases last year involving more than 700 clients, and is supported by public donations, he said. Most of the cases were on religious freedom issues.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Questions Ship's Crew, Officials End Search for Victims
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday completed their search for victims of a fire that swept through a ferry last weekend, and an inquiry heard testimony from an engineer who cited tense relations among crewmembers. The search has ended for victims on board the gutted hulk of the 10,500-ton Scandinavian Star ferry moored in a Swedish port, and officials estimated 160 dead and one person unaccounted for, said police in Oslo, Norway. A list of the victims' names will be issued Monday, police said. Fire broke out on the Danish-owned ferry on April 7 during an overnight run between Oslo and Frederikshavn, Denmark. It was towed to Lysekil, Sweden. Norwegian police have estimated that 534 people were aboard the Scandinavian Star, including 97 crew members. The exact number may never be known because passenger lists did not include young children who traveled free and people who boarded in cars. American entertainer Ruth E. Rome, 27, of East Lansing, Mich., was missing and presumed killed. Police believe that the fire, which started in at least three places, was deliberately set, and they are investigating reports that the arsonist could be a disgruntled crewmember. Manuel Martins, the second engineer, told the fourth day of an inquiry in Copenhagen that the atmosphere between the 16 men in the engine room was tense during the week before the fire. He, along with his Portuguese colleagues, had language difficulties with the Filipino machinists, Martins said. The chief engineer was a West German. Police officers on the inquiry panel, which includes lawyers and marine officials, have asked each of the 12 witnesses called so far whether they'd heard of any trouble among the crew. Martins and the other Portuguese were irritated because the Filipinos had the only keys to the engine room tool chests. Martins said he'd been unable to get access to the tools he needed during the entire week before the disaster. The motors in several of the Scandinavian Star's lifeboats were out of order, and the motors of two of them were removed, Martins said. Earlier witnesses spoke of malfunctioning fire doors and defective fire equipment. None of the witnesses knew the ship's emergency plan or what their own task was in case of fire.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan, PLO Discuss Confederation, PLO Member Says
DOC.TEXT: Government and PLO officials are considering the formation of a Jordanian-Palestinian federation that would follow a Middle East peace accord, a senior PLO representative said Saturday. Mahmoud Abbas, an executive committee member of the Palestine Liberation Organization, made the report after a two-hour meeting with Prime Minister Mudar Badran to prepare for a visit by PLO chief Yasser Arafat. ``The confederation is an issue which was proposed some time ago, and it is accepted to both sides,'' Abbas said. ``And I believe it would not probably be implemented now, but it is in our minds, it exists, it is desired and it is the ideal solution for both of us.'' He said the confederation idea would be a main topic of discussion between King Hussein and Arafat, who is scheduled to visit Amman later in the week. There was no immediate comment Saturday from Jordanian officials. However, the Jordanians lately have said the idea of confederation should be discussed after a Palestinian state is established. The PLO and Jordan agreed in February 1985 to work for a peace settlement with Israel that would lead to a Palestinian state confederated with Jordan. Such a status was intended to help overcome U.S. resistance to a purely independent Palestinian state, and backers argued confederation would benefit both countries economically and socially. Despite the collapse of the 1985 plan a year later, the PLO has continued to advocate confederation. The PLO declared its own Palestinian state in November 1988, three months after King Hussein renounced sovereignty over the Israeli-occupied West Bank in favor of the PLO. Although it did not define the borders of its state, the PLO said it would roughly encompass the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which are occupied by Israel. About half of Jordan's 3.1 million people come from Palestinian families who fled their homes during wars with Israel. Jordan ruled the West Bank from 1949 until it was captured by Israel in 1967. Abbas said Arafat also would discuss the perceived threat of heavy Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel and the occupied territories due to relaxed Soviet immigration rules. He said the PLO was negotiating with the Soviet Union, the United States and Europe ``to halt the influx of Soviet Jews to the occupied territories.'' Abbas welcomed a statement Friday by U.S. Senate Republican leader Robert Dole that he would try to reverse a recent Senate resolution recognizing undivided Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. The Israelis captured parts of Jerusalem during the 1967 Middle East War and later annexed them. They have declared the city their capital. The Senate resolution is not binding on the U.S. administration, which considers east Jerusalem to be occupied territory whose status should be decided by peace talks.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Janitors Reach Pact To End 12-Day Strike
DOC.TEXT: A 12-day janitors' strike that caused trash to pile up at Madrid Airport ended Saturday after a wage increase was agreed on, a union spokesman said. Normal work crews were to return to work late Saturday to clean up the facility that handles thousands of passengers and 500 daily airline flights during the Easter holidays. Restaurant employees and waiters had taken to wearing protective face masks to avoid the stench and possible respiratory infections from the garbage. The accord included a $42 increase in monthly pay, $4 less than the workers were demanding, said the union spokesman, who asked not to be identified. Average base pay for cleaning workers in the Madrid area is $523 a month, according to union statistics. The legal minimum wage in Spain is $472 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Breakthrough In Racing Camels' Procreation Reported
DOC.TEXT: The ancient desert sport of camel racing is going high-tech with the first artificial insemination of the breed, a newspaper reported Saturday. Scientists at the Sheik Khalifa Genetic Research Laboratory have successfully removed and artificially fertilized ovules of famous racing camel breeds, said the state-run newspaper Al-Ittihad. The report described the artificial impregnation as ``a scientific breakthrough in the field of racing camels.'' Camel racing, a former nomadic pastime, is a big sport in the Arab Gulf states, where millions of dollars are spent on races each year. Billionaire sheiks and princes all along the Arabian Peninsula have given a new lease on life to desert camels, breeding them for the November-April season, when desert temperatures cool to a tolerable 95 degrees. Al-Ittihad said the laboratory on the farm of Crown Prince Sheik Khalifa Bin Zayed had achieved successful artificial impregnation after 16 months of research. It quoted officials at the laboratory for its report. United Arab Emirates scientists were aided by counterparts from Australia _ which also has camel racing _ in applying advanced methods normally used on horses and livestock in the West, the report said. Top racing camels can sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars and prizes at bigger meets run as high as $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel Fire Deaths Among Elderly Track National Pattern
DOC.TEXT: The Fontana Hotel blaze that killed nine people proved once again how vulnerable the elderly are in fires, experts say. Though the building housed young adults and children as well as old people, the youngest victim was 75. ``I believe they couldn't hear,'' said Max Goldstein, 84, who got out with his wife, Gertrude, after hearing the manager's warning and the fire alarm April 6 at the Miami Beach hotel. ``No, it's because they couldn't get out,'' said his neighbor, Sylvia Pollen, noting one woman who used a walker died in the elevator and another victim had difficulty walking. ``A mixture of both,'' Goldstein concluded as he waited in line last week for a chance to return to his top-floor room in the three-story hotel destroyed in the pre-dawn fire. The 102-room hotel built in 1951 met fire codes, and investigators are dealing with a devastating death toll in a sound structure. The ages of the victims ranged from 75 to 93. Investigators have not determined the cause, but on Friday ruled out arson and placed the starting point in a crawl space next to an elevator shaft. Fire Chief Braniard Dorris said the investigation must determine why the fire cut the victims off from the fire exits. Although many Miami Beach hotels are retirement homes, the Fontana's 100 residents ranged from babies to frail seniors. ``It wasn't a building that housed only the old elderly or that housed the disabled elderly,'' said police Detective Jim Hyde. ``It had a very big mix among the tenants.'' Fires kill people age 75 and older at three times the national average, and almost one-fifth of fire victims age 65 and older are bedridden or physically handicapped, according to the National Fire Protection Association. The elderly are more likely to die because smoke aggravates any respiratory problems, and they tend to walk upright rather than crouch or crawl to avoid smoke, said Leeann Steinberg of the American Association of Retired Persons. The Fontana fire had other aspects that made it typical of fatal fires. The fire began about 3 a.m.; the U.S. Fire Administration reports fatal fires are most common between 1 and 3 a.m. And all but 1.4 percent of deaths are recorded in buildings, like the Fontana, without sprinkler systems. ``There has never been a multiple fatality in a properly sprinklered building,'' said Tim Butters, spokesman for the 10,000-member International Association of Fire Chiefs in Washington. Existing hotels and motels in Florida will be required to install sprinklers by October 1991, and Dorris estimates 25 to 30 hotels along the high-rise studded beach already have complied or are installing systems now. Fontana residents commended a Romanian immigrant family who bought the hotel for $1.6 million last June for making major improvements, but a $150,000 sprinkler system was still ahead. Asked if sprinklers would have saved lives, Hyde said, ``The people in the fire marshal's office think definitely.'' Goldstein, who has alternated six months at the Fontana and six months in New York City, isn't sure what his plans are now. When his wife wanders into the hotel parking lot, where debris is stacked 10 feet high beside the building, Goldstein shakes his head and says: ``She thinks she's still at the hotel. She's in bad shape.'' ``Believe me, I'm not right,'' he says, stressing he is still absorbing the fire losses. ``I'll be 110 when I get through with this.''

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Party Leader Says He Wants to Work with Opposition
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party General Secretary Gombogavyn Ochirbat has reaffirmed his willingness to work with new opposition parties in introducing democratic reform. A new party Central Committee on Friday re-elected Ochirbat to the post he first was given one month ago after opposition protests forced out the old party leadership. ``We shall take a position of mutual understanding, cooperate with (the opposition) and hold political dialogue,'' Ochirbat told a television interviewer Friday night at the conclusion of an extraordinary party congress. The opposition, inspired by the fall of communism elsewhere in the Soviet bloc, has emerged since December to demand a share of power. The nation has been ruled for nearly seven decades by the Communists, formally known as the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party. In a session that ended just before dawn Friday, the extraordinary congress elected the new Central Committee, paring it down from 146 members to 91. It also rewrote the party constitution to make it more democratic. The new Central Committee met immediately to confirm Ochirbat in his post. It also reappointed four other members of the party's top decision-making body, the Politburo, and added a sixth member, Sumya, who was culture minister until midweek. The Central Committee gave the Politburo a new name, the Presidium, but did not change its basic function or powers. The new party constitution, however, abolishes the formal requirement of absolute obedience to the center, and allows local party bodies to raise objections to orders from the top. It also gives them a small degree of financial independence. Ochirbat also promised that people being laid off in a reorganization of the government will be given new jobs. Last week, the government disbanded two ministries or ministry-level committees and merged two with other ministries. News reports said about 2,000 people would be laid off. Meanwhile, the new challenge to authority in the political sphere spread to the already-stagnant economy as workers at two Soviet joint ventures went on strike. About 150 truck drivers at a Soviet construction company in the city of Darhan walked off Saturday morning to protest plans to lay them off, said Javkhlant, a member of the opposition Mongolian Democratic Association. He said about 34 workers at a Soviet joint venture coal mine in Baganuur struck earlier in the week for better working conditions, but agreed to return to work at least temporarily Saturday while awaiting a response from the company. He said Mongolian Democratic Association members were on the strike committees, but had not started the strikes. The government already has warned that national industrial output in the first quarter fell from last year, and it has blamed the growing mood of lax discipline.

DOC.HEAD: Children From Crime-Ridden Housing Project to Exhibit Art at Gallery
DOC.TEXT: Eleven-year-old Isaiah Brooms, whose bedroom wall was pierced by a bullet one night while he slept, once dreamed he saw his artwork ``in a painting museum.'' Starting Monday night, Isaiah comes close to that vision when one of his drawings goes up at the Quinlan Gallery. The gallery in a fashionable North Side neighborhood is featuring art by children from Cabrini-Green _ one of the nation's most notorious housing projects. ``I think the kids will be proud of themselves,'' said gallery owner Mickey Quinlan, who mounted the show to help celebrate the 25th anniversary of a tutoring program at Cabrini. The exhibit, titled ``Cabrini's Creations,'' will feature the work of about 125 children and run through the end of April. Proceeds from sales of their work will go to charity. The show had its seeds in a meeting last year between Quinlan, the mother of 11, and Isaiah. She liked his artwork and included two pieces in a show. ``I felt like I was special, because I never had my pictures hung up in a gallery before,'' said Isaiah, a sixth-grader who wears clear-framed eyeglasses that slip down his nose. This year, Quinlan was motivated to extend the opportunity to other children from Cabrini, and the result is the exhibit that opens Monday. Isaiah's contribution to the current show is a crayon drawing showing favorite childhood pastimes: bowling, playing video games, shooting basketball hoops, and getting pop from a soda machine. But instead of depicting each activity in a wide long shot, Isaiah does closeups of hands: hands with balls, hands with video games, a hand on a pop machine. One of the other works in the show has the words, ``Art is free'' written on it, Quinlan said. ``It just makes you feel real good. It almost makes you want to weep,'' she said. One mile to the south of the gallery, Cabrini-Green is a zone of 78 battered apartment buildings operated by the Chicago Housing Authority, home to about 13,800 people. About three-fourths of them are children. Seventy-five percent of CHA residents are unemployed, and 85 percent of families are headed by single women, CHA spokeswoman Lucille Wallace said. To children from Cabrini-Green, the Quinlan Gallery neighborhood is ``another world,'' said Geraldine Mansueto, who tutors Isaiah. ``These kids don't get a lot of recognition,'' she said. ``For them to be in a gallery on Halsted Street in Lincoln Park _ that's something that's out of their ken.'' Even with tighter security measures in some buildings, violent crimes including murder, rape and arson are being reported at a rate of more than one a day at Cabrini, 1989 CHA statistics show. Isaiah's mother, 33-year-old Clara Brooms, described entering her son's bedroom after a night of gunfire about three years ago and discovering a bullet hole in the wall above his pillow. ``When I woke up, I said, `God, all this shooting.' I said, `Let me go in, my baby could be dead.' I got in there, and the first thing I saw was the hole right over his head. ``Then I went to the window and said, `Oh, my God!''' The security measures have helped improve the picture somewhat since then, she and Isaiah said. Derek Ellis, another exhibit participant from Cabrini-Green, draws in pencil, producing likenesses of figures in magazines and pictures. Derek, 14, shares a bedroom with his 12-year-old sister and 8-year-old twin brothers. The boys sleep in one bed, their sister in another. Derek says he thinks about becoming an artist or a pro basketball player some day. Isaiah says he wants to be either a professional artist or a data processor _ or both _ when he grows up. One time, Isaiah said, ``I dreamed my stuff was in a painting museum,'' like the Art Institute of Chicago. Isaiah's tutor says he ``likes being the best.'' ``He likes being No. 1,'' she said. ``I think that's going to save him more than anything else.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Removing Space Telescope Batteries for Recharging
DOC.TEXT: NASA opened Discovery's payload bay doors Saturday to remove the Hubble Space Telescope's batteries for recharging and to replace a faulty part in preparation for an April 25 launch. Technicians took out a faulty auxiliary power unit responsible for grounding the shuttle last week. A new unit was being installed to be tested Sunday and fired up briefly later this week. ``We haven't run into any problem,'' said Lisa Malone, a spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``We're looking good for the 25th.'' Hubble's six nickel-hydrogen batteries will be recharged for 5{ days in a laboratory at the Vehicle Assembly Building. NASA decided to take the batteries there because they can be recharged at a cooler temperature and thus retain more power. ``We will have a higher capacity in them than we would have had we been recharging at the pad,'' said Fred Wojtalik, a NASA project manager. ``This will make the opportunities for additional launch days a lot easier for us.'' The batteries will power Hubble from the time it is disconnected from the shuttle's power system during deployment until its energy-collecting solar panels are unfurled. Discovery was poised for launch Tuesday, but the mission was scrubbed four minutes before liftoff when the auxiliary power unit failed. NASA was not sure how long it would take to replace the 88-pound unit because the procedure had never been performed before at the launch pad. The work went smoothly, Malone said. The defective power unit was returned to the manufacturer, Sunstrand Corp. of Rockford, Ill., for testing. The shuttle's three auxiliary power units pressurize the hydraulic system, which is used to move wing and rudder surfaces and in the ship's braking and steering systems. NASA planned to close Discovery's payload bay doors Sunday as soon as the lengthy process of removing the batteries was completed. The chamber will remain sealed to reduce the risk of getting too much dust on the telescope's 94-inch mirror, the finest ever made, until the batteries are returned next weekend. The $1.5 billion telescope is NASA's most expensive and complex payload. Once it is in orbit above Earth's distorting atmosphere, it will be able to detect objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best observatory on the ground. Astronomers expect to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years, close to the beginning of the universe.

DOC.HEAD: Aggressive `Killer Bees' Expected to Buzz Into U.S. Any Day
LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: The first swarm of Africanized honey bees will buzz north across the Rio Grande any day now, but scientists say the worst sting of the ``killer bees'' may be economic. Researchers predict the bees probably will enter the United States near the border city of Brownsville. In November, they were spotted 150 miles south of the border at Soto la Marina, Mexico, near the Gulf Coast. None has been found near the border since, but their advance accelerates with as spring flowers provide food, said Anita Collins, head researcher at the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Honey Bee Research Lab at Weslaco. These bees, descended from a tough African strain, have been spreading across South and Central America and Mexico since they escaped from a now-infamous Brazilian research program in 1957. Along the way they've killed an estimated 600 people, mostly in tropical South America, to earn their ominous nickname. An Africanized bee's sting is no worse than a European bee's, but they were tagged ``killers'' because they tend to protect their colonies at the slightest disturbance, sending hundreds or thousands of defenders against intruders. Africanized bees abscond from hives to form new colonies more regularly than the European honey bees commonly used in the Americas for pollinating crops and producing honey. The difficulty of managing Africanized bees eventually will cost U.S. beekeepers $29 million to $58 million a year, the USDA estimates. Africanized bees also are expected to reduce bee-pollinated crop production by 5 percent to 10 percent, costing farmers more than $40 million a year. Bee pollination adds nearly $800 million in value, it is estimated, to U.S. crops each year. U.S. residents along the border aren't likely to notice much change, beyond seeing more wild colonies and swarms of bees looking for nest sites, said Ms. Collins, who has studied the Africanized bees for 14 years. ``They'll see bees ... much more frequently than they're used to,'' she said. Some danger remains, she said, noting that in Venezuela a swarm chased her and other scientists to a truck about 100 yards away. Researchers are monitoring 318 bee traps in southern Texas, as far west as Del Rio and as far north as the Aransas National Wildlife Refuge north of Corpus Christi, to track the bees' movement. There are 60,000 traps in Mexico. Scientists will keep an eye on southern Texas and northern Mexico and destroy as many Africanized swarms as possible to slow their progress and buy time for research, Ms. Collins said. ``We're not going to try and sit on the border and destroy every swarm that comes across,'' she said. ``This is an attempt to reduce these first pioneer swarms. But at some point, we're going to be overwhelmed.'' No one knows how far north the bees will spread before the cold stops their expansion. In the Southern Hemisphere, they have not moved south of 32 degrees latitude, which north of the equator would mean Central Texas. The bees travel 250 to 350 miles a year, Ms. Collins said. The first confirmed trapping in Texas will trigger an emergency plan, although the inter-agency Texas Honey Bee Management Plan is still being designed and has yet to get state funds. The first step in the plan is a quarantine keeping anyone from moving bees out of the state's eight southernmost counties, said John Fick, one of the state's two apiary inspectors with the Texas Agricultural Experiment Station. Beekeepers will be called on to ensure their queens remain European, since researchers believe European bees moderate the Africanized bees' behavior through interbreeding. Scientists and beekeepers shun the ``killer bee'' appellation, and the Texas Beekeepers Association has launched a public relations campaign to tell people the Africanized bee won't be out searching for victims. Fifteen to 20 people already die in the United States each year from allergic reactions to bee stings, the association points out. Marilee Mace, who runs a crop pollination business with her husband, Glenn, president of the beekeepers association, believes beekeepers will remain the strongest line of defense. ``It's very important that we keep a healthy beekeeping industry, because if we lose those bees, then we have to live with whatever has moved into that void,'' she said. ``And we don't want to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Protester in Pakistan Ends Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: An Indian immigrant leader ended a six-day hunger strike Saturday after assurances that officials will work to ease tensions that led to clashes killing up to 60 people in recent weeks, a governor said. Altaf Hussein, who leads the Qaumi Mohajir Movement of Indian immigrants, launched his hunger strike Sunday, demanding several supporters be freed. They were arrested in connection with the recent violence. The main combatants in the past month's political violence have been Hussein's group and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. On April 6 in Karachi, marauding gunmen killed 17 people and wounded 55. Thirty people were later arrested. Half belonged to Hussein's party and the other half were members of Ms. Bhutto's party. Hussein's hunger strike ended after a four-hour meeting with Fakhruddin Ibrahim, governor of the southern province of Sindh. Ibrahim is a member of Ms. Bhutto's party, which dominates the provincial assembly. ``I'm pleased to announce that Hussein accepted my request to call off his hunger strike in the greater interest of the nation,'' Ibrahim told reporters following his meeting. ``We assured him that we will work for peace in Sindh and we will provide justice for each and everyone living in Sindh,'' he said. Hussein declined to comment Saturday. His movement has charged its members are denied jobs and promotions in favor of indigenous Sindhis, a charge denied by Sindhi nationalists. Up to 10,000 soldiers have been patrolling in Karachi since the start of Hussein's hunger strike.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Awaiting Detailed Account of Threat to Lithuania
With AM-Lithuania Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 17th graf pvs, bgng: A persistent, to UPDATE with Bush arriving at Andrews AFB
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sought more detailed information Saturday on Moscow's threat of economic retaliation against Lithuania, while Senate Democrats condemned Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev for taking ``precisely the wrong approach'' to the latest crisis. During a rain-soaked game of golf, Bush told reporters he wanted to withhold further comment on the situation until he received ``a clarification'' on Gorbachev's ultimatum to the independence-seeking Baltic republic. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, said the administration was taking a `wait and see'' attitude. ``It's not entirely easy to know what the next moves are going to be,'' Baker said in an interview on Cable News Network. Imposition of sanctions, he added, ``would have an adverse impact'' on U.S.-Soviet relations. Baker would not speculate on what form a U.S. response to sanctions would take. Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Friday they were deeply disturbed by Gorbachev's threat to cut off supplies to Lithuania if it did not rescind laws passed since it asserted independence on March 11. A senior administration official said that the Soviet ultimatum caught U.S. strategists off guard and that Gorbachev's move was undergoing close analysis and scrutiny in the United States. The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that there would probably be a further U.S. response to the action before the end of the weekend. The official said, however, the range of options was very limited _ adding to the frustration felt by the administration as the war of nerves between the Baltic state and the Kremlin continues to intensify. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and six Democratic colleagues, just returned to Washington from a visit with Gorbachev in Moscow, condemned the economic ultimatum as ``precisely the wrong approach in such a delicate and dangerous situation.'' At a news conference at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., Mitchell noted that on Thursday Gorbachev had expressed to the Senate delegation ``his intention to resolve the situation in Lithuania by peaceful, non-violent means.'' Mitchell and Sens. Bill Bradley of New Jersey, John Glenn of Ohio, Wyche Fowler of Georgia, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, Paul Sarbanes of Maryland and Tom Daschle of South Dakota all expressed dismay that Gorbachev had leveled the economic threat just a day later. ``An act need not involve direct violence to be wrong,'' said Mitchell. ``The action taken yesterday was wrong. We condemn it.'' Mitchell said he and the other senators likely would meet with Bush early in the week to report on their trip, which included visits to Berlin and Leningrad as well as the two-hour session with Gorbachev. Daschle said Gorbachev had told the group that ``he felt like he had led three lives since 1975, and that this year was the most difficult of all.'' And he quoted Gorbachev as saying that Lithuania's political uprising was ``a gift to my hardliners.'' The domestic Soviet upheaval was casting a pall over Bush's May 30-June 3 superpower session with Gorbachev, where both leaders have suggested they hope to be able to initial a new agreement to limit long-range nuclear weapons. A persistent, wind-driven rain did little to discourage the president from playing 18 holes of golf on this British island colony before heading back to the United States. He returned to Andrews Air Force Base, Md., near Washington late Saturday afternoon and boarded a helicopter for the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., where he was to spend the rest of the weekend. Reflecting on Friday's meetings with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Bush said, ``It's very important that we stay on the same wave length.'' He said his administration and Thatcher's government ``feel very comfortable about our positions'' on East-West issues. Despite ``slight nuances on a few things, differences,'' the two allies are ``very close together,'' Bush said. Mrs. Thatcher's husband, Denis, joined Bush for the soggy golf outing. Also in the presidential party were Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Chief of Staff John Sununu, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and White House physician Burton Lee. Asked about the latest Gorbachev threat, Bush said, ``I haven't heard anything about anything yet. I haven't seen the intelligence report yet. I will when I get in.'' He said that after his joint news confernce with Thatcher on Friday afternoon, ``I wanted a clarification'' from Moscow on Gorbachev's warning to Lithuania. But, Bush said, ``It was midnight over there.'' Bush was to complete a trio of pre-superpower-summit meetings with allied leaders next Thursday when he meets with French President Francois Mitterrand in Key Largo, Florida. He conferred with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney last Tuesday in Toronto.

DOC.HEAD: One-Party Rule Violates Rights, Say Churches
DOC.TEXT: Church leaders on Saturday criticized plans for a one-party state and said steps to create it will infringe on fundamental human rights in one of Africa's few Western-style democracies. The Roman Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace urged President Robert Mugabe's governing party to abandon its commitment to one-party rule. The statement comes four days before safeguards for political opposition _ guaranteed for 10 years in the 1980 British-brokered constitution _ expire. ``We believe that a constitutionalized one-party state is contrary to basic human rights,'' the 35-member commission said at the end of a two-day meeting. A one-party system of government as envisaged by Mugabe's governing Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front) ``ends up benefiting chiefly the people already entrenched in powerful positions,'' the church commission said. ``No generation has the right to make immutable decisions for future generations,'' it said. In one of its strongest attacks on Mugabe's policies, the commission said the freedom to vote for a political party of choice was a fundamental right, along with the freedoms of association, assembly and speech enshrined in constitutional law. It urged the governing party to rule with a mandate based on freedom of choice and its own efficiency and ``credibility of performance.'' After the governing party won 116 of 119 seats contested by five parties in parliamentary elections last month, Mugabe said the victory at the polls gave him the backing he needed to establish a one-party system along Marxist lines. He has repeatedly argued that a plural system creates division that hinders development. Since Zimbabwe's independence in 1980, the governing party has abided by the British-mediated constitution containing safeguards for political opposition. Those safeguards expire when Zimbabwe celebrates its 10th anniversary of independence from white minority rule on Wednesday, but Mugabe has said he will not immediately outlaw opposition parties.

DOC.HEAD: Guinea-Bissau Accuses Senegal of Attack on Soviet Boat
DOC.TEXT: In a simmering maritime feud between two West African nations, Guinea-Bissau accused Senegal's navy of entering its waters, seizing a Soviet fishing boat and shooting at it, a report said Saturday. Guinea-Bissau has claimed the disputed section off the Atlantic coast, which potentially contains oil, since independence from Portugal in 1974. No casualties were reported in the incident Wednesday, according to a Guinea-Bissau government statement quoted by the Portuguese news agency Lusa. Guinea-Bissau's foreign minister, Julio Semedo, called the seizure of the Orleonok, ``a flagrant violantion of sovereignty .. . and international law,'' and demanded the immediate release of the boat, Lusa reported from Bissau, the country's capital. The incident is the latest in a series of clashes over a disputed maritime frontier which have soured relations between Guinea-Bissau and Senegal, a former French colony. Guinea-Bissau's navy fired on a Senegalese fishing boat in the disputed waters last year and in January, Bissau accused Senegal's air force of repeated violations of its airspace. The disputed waters lie just off the land border between Senegal and Guinea-Bissau. The zone was listed as Senegalese territory in 1960 by an exchange of letters between Portugal and France. A World Court ruling upheld that decision last year.

DOC.HEAD: Public Defender Appointed To Represent Man Charged With Strangling Six
DOC.TEXT: A man described as ``real likable'' and concerned over the safety of older residents of his homeless shelter was arraigned Saturday on charges of killing six of seven black women found strangled here. The arrest of Ray Shawn Jackson, 22, came after another incident Monday in which a black woman was attacked and choked by an assailant who was scared away by a man out walking his dog. Associate Jackson County Circuit Judge George Aylward appointed the public defender's office to represent Jackson and scheduled his formal arraignment for April 25. Aylward continued bond at $700,000 _ $100,000 each on the six first-degree murder charges and the same amount for first-degree assault in the Monday attack. The woman attacked then, who said she was knocked to the ground and choked by an assailant, identified Jackson from a photograph as her attacker. Police Chief Larry Joiner estimated police had put in between 8,000 and 12,000 hours of investigation since Sept. 16, when the first of the killings in or near a midtown park occurred. ``The police work in this was incredible, it really was,'' Pat Peters, assistant Jackson County prosecutor, said after Saturday's court appearance. A composite picture of a suspect was released last weekend, after the body of Michelle Mitchell, 22, was found April 5. The picture led to more than 300 phone calls, Joiner said. Information that led officers to Jackson was developed during a neighborhood canvass Thursday by detectives. They found him at his grandmother's home, where he sometimes stayed, and he agreed to come to headquarters for questioning that resulted in the charges. Joiner said that all six women had been lured to their deaths by the offer of obtaining crack cocaine. Probable cause statements filed with the charges said Jackson told police he killed the women. Jackson's sister, who would identify herself only as Kim, told The Kansas City Star he was someone who ``didn't want to listen.'' Snapping her fingers, she said, ``He'd be the sweetest person you'd ever know, and then, something would happen.'' ``Number one, yes, my brother said he committed those murders,'' she said. ``Number two, we don't know why. He's hardheaded like any other normal person.'' William Johns, who knew Jackson from a homeless shelter where they both spent time, called him ``real likable.'' He and others there said he didn't smoke or drink and while he got into an occasional fight, he would sometimes escort older people from the shelter to a nearby liquor store to keep them safe. In addition to Ms. Mitchell, Jackson is charged with killing Annette Stewart, 33, whose body was found Sept. 16; Kimberly Creer, 22, found Sept. 20; Tresa Williams, 21, found Oct. 22; Janice Berryman, 36, found Oct. 28; and Tonya Ward, 23, found Jan. 18. Joiner said the investigation had not produced evidence linking Jackson to the death of the seventh woman, Brenda McCoy, 33, who was found Sept. 26.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Continues At State Broadcasting Network
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 union workers at the state-run broadcasting network went on strike Saturday, protesting the appointment of a former government spokesman as their new boss. The walkout, which began Thursday, has paralyzed the KBS radio and television network and workers pledged to continue the protests until president Suh Ki-won resigns. The network's five radio stations and two television channels remained on the air with the help of technical staffs and other non-union members, but news programs and other live broadcasts have been cut short or replaced with movies, documentaries and pre-recorded dramas. The network's radio stations all broadcast the same program, consisting mostly of music. About 5,000 of the network's 18,000 employees are unionized, mostly reporters, producers and directors, camera crews and administrative personnel. The workers claim that government's appointment of Suh, a former government spokesman, reflects Seoul's new efforts to gain control of the country's news media, including KBS, which is fighting for press freedom. The protest began Thursday when hundreds of workers occupied a section of the network's main office in Seoul to prevent Suh from assuming his post. Suh entered his sixth floor office through an underground garage and requested police intervention. About 500 riot police stormed the building and arrested 117 workers. The protests spread quickly to the network's 26 local stations, which also were on strike. Hundreds of local union workers traveled to join their colleagues in Seoul. On Saturday, police released 10 more workers, including union leader Ahn Dong-soo, 42, after freeing 97 a day earlier. About 1,000 riot police, posted in and around the network's office, also were withdrawn Saturday in an apparent effort to defuse the confrontation.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Democracy Movement Archive at N.Y. Public Library
With AM-China-Anniversary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some of the writing that emanated from last spring's pro- democracy demonstrations in Beijing's Tiananmen Square has been saved for historians in the New York Public Library. About 700 items _ declarations, poetry, newsletters and the like _ were gathered in China by Robin Munro, a researcher for the human rights group Asia Watch. The material has been donated to archives about the pro-democracy movement around the world, including one at the library in Manhattan. Munro said he started collecting as soon as he arrived in Beijing in May on the second day of the students' hunger strike. He left two weeks after the army moved in and suppressed the demonstrations on June 3-4, when hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people were killed. Munro's collection is the heart of primary source material in the New York archive, which is made up of several thousand items stored in a small metal filing cabinet and on a few bookshelves. The archive is not imposing, but large enough to give scholars material for analyzing the movement from many angles. ``Politically, we want to be impartial. So not only do we get lots of anti-government material but we also give the Chinese government a chance to have their material included,'' said librarian John T. Ma, in charge of Chinese materials in the library's Oriental Division. The Chinese consul general in New York responded to a request from Ma by donating books and cassette tapes about what the government called counterrevolutionary turmoil last spring. Ma said the library also obtained correspondence and other papers from the U.S. office of the Front for a Democratic China, an umbrella organization that includes movement leaders in exile. That material includes personal papers of student leader Wu'er Kaixi and the office's director, Jin Yanshi, Ma said. The archive also includes local material about the movement from New York's large Chinese community, said Lucy Kung of the library's Economic and Public Affairs Division. Ms. Kung, like Ma, is volunteering time to solicit and organize the materials since the library has no money budgeted for the archive, Ma said. John M. Lundquist, chief librarian of the Oriental Division, said material continues to arrive, partly thanks to Ma and Ms. Kung's extensive contacts. Ma said many people with materials about the movement have been eager to donate them because of their historical value. ``Chinese usually are very mindful of historical mission,'' he said. ``Chinese follow history as a guidepost, not the Bible.'' American universities with major Chinese studies divisions also are developing collections about the democracy movement. Lundquist said the New York Library is working on its archive in cooperation with such schools as Harvard, Yale and Columbia. Munro said he also gave copies of his collection to archives at Harvard and the British Library, as well as others in Hong Kong, Chicago and Liden, the Netherlands. The New York collection also includes a tape of music composed by Taiwanese musicians that was played during Tiananmen Square demonstrations, a videotape of a news conference by Chinese officials, and video footage of televised news reports from around the world showing how the story was reported.

DOC.HEAD: Woman and Daughter Overwhelm Alleged Purse-snatcher
DOC.TEXT: A would-be purse-snatcher who threatened two women, saying he had a weapon, was overpowered and held by the women until police arrived, authorities said. ``He said, `I have a knife.' So I gave up trying to hold onto my purse. But my daughter jumped on him and I had to help her. He was tall, but not strong,'' said Rumiko Sera, 57, of the attempted robbery Wednesday. ``I just wanted to detain him,'' said Sera's 31-year-old daughter, Ann Kunitake. ``He kept saying that he had a knife and was going to kill us. I didn't believe him. If he did, why didn't he bring it out?'' Bystanders helped the women hold onto the man, who ``kept spitting on the men and saying he was going to give them AIDS,'' Kunitake said. Police arrested Lino Ochoa, 28, for investigation of robbery. Ochoa pleaded innocent Friday to unrelated charges of robbery and assault with a deadly weapon, said Deputy District Attorney Michael Pargament. He said Ochoa also is accused of two other purse-snatching incidents, and allegedly has been driving a car that was reported stolen April 3.

DOC.HEAD: Death Of A Cop Killer Prompts Local, Federal Investigations
DOC.TEXT: Adolph Archie died, messily, after 13 hours in the custody of police who arrested him for the fatal shooting of a police officer. He had a cracked skull, a crushed larynx, a shattered face and too many bloody bruises to count, according to the autopsy his family commissioned. ``There is no question: This man was beaten to death,'' the family's attorney, Mary Howell, said last week at a news conference. ``If I may be more specific, he was stomped to death.'' The allegations have led to investigations by police, Orleans Parish District Attorney Harry Connick and U.S. Attorney John Volz. Civil rights leaders, meanwhile, accuse Orleans Parish Coroner Frank Minyard of releasing an incomplete autopsy report and of trying to cover up a homicide to protect the police. They demand that he resign. No one disputes that Archie, a black man, was a career criminal or that he killed police officer Earl Hauck, a white man. ``He should have been arrested, tried and executed for killing that policeman,'' said the Rev. Marie Galatas, head of the city's Grass Roots Organization for Women. ``But he should have gone through a court system.'' GROW and Southern Christian Leadership Conference officials say police officers have told them confidentially that four officers, three white and one black, were involved in beating Archie. The civil rights groups have declined to release details on those allegations, saying the officers fear for their jobs and won't go public. Archie, 40, had nine criminal convictions behind him when he ran away from a parish prison work detail on March 8. On March 22, police said, a security guard surprised him while he was breaking into a parked car at the Louisiana Superdome. Archie punched the guard, stole her gun and ran. Hauck, directing traffic downtown, joined the chase and was fatally shot after cornering Archie near an office building loading dock. Archie hid under a parked car. Police pulled him out. Then, the story becomes cloudy. Archie, shot in the forearm and slightly injured during the chase, apparently also suffered some injuries while being pulled from under the car, but the extent of his injuries isn't clear. He was taken to Charity Hospital, but wasn't admitted. Hauck, too, was taken to Charity, where he was pronounced dead. Police Chief Warren Woodfork said police decided to take Archie from Charity to the 1st District police station where Hauck had worked because Hauck's fellow officers were at Charity and Archie might be in danger there. At the police station, police said Archie tried to grab a gun and was knocked backward, hitting his head on the floor. There were no reports that might account for the numerous other injuries Archie suffered. Archie was held for about 45 minutes before police decided to take him back to Charity, where he was admitted. The next morning, Archie was lying on a table, awaiting a CAT scan, when he became agitated, ripped a tracheal tube from his throat and died before the tube could be reinserted, according to hospital reports and Minyard, the coroner. The direct cause of death, said Minyard, was the removal of the tracheal tube. ``I'm saying that the man received a trauma in police custody, but that did not cause his death,'' the coroner said. That's not entirely true, says a report by Dr. Kris Sperry, a Fulton County, Ga., forensic pathologist hired by the family attorney to do an independent autopsy. Archie needed the tracheal tube because of severe injuries inflicted in a fight with one or more people, Sperry said in his report, which concludes that ``the manner of death is homicide.'' Minyard's staff autopsy lists many of the injuries Sperry found, but makes no specific references to injuries of Archie's chest, abdomen and testicles, Sperry said. And, while Minyard reported a single fracture to the skull, Sperry's report lists two fractures, beginning on opposite sides of Archie's head and extending to the back of the skull. Woodfork said last month that he saw no evidence of wrongdoing, but police have had no comment since then, saying their investigation is under way. Since Sperry's report came out last week, Minyard has declined comment on the case. At an April 4 news conference, Minyard said his staff's autopsy was as thorough as it could be given the limited time available _ about two hours _ in an office that deals with at least one murder almost every day. Minyard wouldn't speculate on when Archie suffered the fractured skull or broken facial bones listed in his and other autopsies. The coroner said he believes police accounts of Archie's handling. He also admitted to a bias in favor of the police. ``I mean, we had two murders this morning,'' he said. ``Every day I work with homicide. And if I don't believe them, I mean, the whole system breaks down. I have to believe what they tell me.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Aides Call for Quick Economic Action
DOC.TEXT: Senior advisers to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared at a special session Saturday that delays in carrying out economic reform are no longer possible, Tass reported. Gorbachev convened his advisers to discuss plans for a controlled market economy, the state-run media said. On Monday, Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin said economists have been unable to draw the final outline of radical reforms to go into effect this summer. Without a transition to a market economy, the Soviet Union has ``no future as a highly developed great power,'' Abalkin said. The Soviet economy is plagued by lagging productivity and severe shortages of consumer goods. Several officials have suggested the Soviet Union was developing an economic ``shock therapy'' plan that would raise prices, drastically cut the value of the ruble and raise unemployment. Poland has a similar program. Speakers at Saturday's session agreed that delays in implementing economic reform were no longer possible, Tass, the official Soviet news agency, reported. The participants decided to continue their session this week, Tass said without elaboration.

DOC.HEAD: Jaruzelski Visits Katyn, Says `Truth is Healing the Wounds'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 18th `Jaruzelski's trip...' to UPDATE with Jaruzelski returning to Warsaw; pickup 19th `At a...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOS16,18
DOC.TEXT: Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski went to the Katyn Forest on Saturday and paid tribute to the thousands of Polish army officers killed and buried there by the Soviet Union's secret police during World War II. His visit came one day after the Soviet government reversed nearly 50 years of official denial and admitted committing the massacre. The Soviet Union had long blamed Nazi Germany. ``The truth was said about Katyn, and the truth is healing the wounds,'' Jaruzelski said in Russian, his voice soft and wavering with emotion. ``Now it will be easier for us to understand each other,'' he told Soviet reporters. The Katyn massacre has long been a strain on relations between the Soviet Union and Poland. Jaruzelski was accompanied by an honor guard of the Polish army at the memorial site in the forest near the western town of Smolensk as he honored the more than 4,000 officers killed in 1940 by Stalin's secret police, the Polish PAP news agency reported. A ``roll call of the dead'' was intoned _ a ceremony in which the names of victims are read, PAP said. In footage broadcast on Soviet TV's evening newscast ``Vremya,'' Jaruzelski, wearing a green army overcoat, green scarf and military cap, stood ramrod straight as two soldiers carried a large wreath of red and white carnations and laid it in front of a memorial to the dead. The monument reads in Russian: ``To the Polish officers fallen in Katyn.'' Polish radio reported Saturday night that the wording on the monument was changed three days ago, removing the words that blamed Nazi Germany. The Soviets had long said the Nazis were responsible for the massacre, in which the Polish officers were shot in the back of the head and stacked on top of each other in mass graves. The honor guard fired a rifle salute, Polish radio said. PAP added that Jaruzelski wrote in the visitor's book: ``They fought for an independent Poland. They died innocently, far-removed from their families and homeland. They were faithful to Poland and to military honor until they breathed their last. In tribute and in lasting memory to Polish officers, victims of the cruel Stalinist crime.'' Jaruzelski also went to the town of Lenino in the nearby republic of Byelorussia and laid wreaths on the graves of Soviet and Polish soldiers at a memorial there, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. The Soviet Union on Friday admitted that the NKVD, Stalin's feared secret police, was responsible for the murders 49 years ago of the Polish officers who had been captured at the start of World War II. The Soviet statement Friday said archive material discovered recently showed that the murders were the work of Stalin's secret police chief Lavrenti Beria, his protege V.N. Merkulov and others. ``The Soviet side, expressing its deep regret in connection with the Katyn tragedy, states that it is one of the most horrifying Stalinist crimes,'' said the statement, carried by Tass. More than 10,000 other Polish officers were killed in camps elsewhere. Their bodies never have been found, but in its statement, the Soviet Union clearly tied together the fates of all 15,000 officers. Jaruzelski's trip to Katyn capped an official visit to the Soviet Union. He returned to Warsaw later Saturday. At a dinner Friday night, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called the Katyn tragedy one of the historical ``knots'' that cast a shadow on Polish-Soviet relations, but he added that ``many of them have already been undone.'' In remarks carried by Tass, Gorbachev said ``genuine renewal and genuine mutual understanding lies only through telling the truth.'' Jaruzelski told the Soviet leader that the Soviet admission on Katyn was ``particularly important and valuable to the Polish people from the moral point of view,'' and he said Poles would not blame the massacre on the Soviet people who themselves suffered under Stalin.

DOC.HEAD: Hail in Texas, Rain Falls Across South
DOC.TEXT: Large hail fell along a fast-moving cold front in Texas on Saturday, and rain fell across the South and into the Great Lakes region. A few showers and thunderstorms were scattered from eastern North Carolina to southern Florida. Showers also scattered rain along the northern Rockies and upper Plains. Rainshowers prevailed from Kentucky northward to the lower Great Lakes region, and the cold front pushed showers and thunderstorms from coastal Texas to western Tennessee. A twister damaged several buildings in southeast Texas, and funnel clouds were sighted in northern Texas, but no injuries were reported. In Bay City, the tornado demolished a wall of a wholesale distributing company and broke windows at Pierce Elementary School and a sporting goods company. ``We've got trees down all over town, and one fell on a vehicle, but there was no one in it,'' said police dispatcher Isa Cox. Large hail fell Friday in central Oklahoma, where golf ball-size hail was reported six inches deep along Interstate 40 near El Reno, Okla., the National Weather Service said. A tornado also was spawned southeast of Watonga, and winds gusted to 75 mph at Okarche in Oklahoma. The hail-producing thunderstorms continued early Saturday, as large hail fell across much of north central Texas. Softball-size hail was reported northwest of Rotan, Texas. Winds pushed by offshore thunderstorms gusted to 59 mph at Port Arthur, and high winds were reported in Houston and Galveston. A car was blown off the road and downed trees and power lines at Bevil Oaks, also in the region. Winds damaged roofs west of Galveston Bay, and small hail fell over parts of Galveston Island. Heavy rain fell in north central Texas, and parts of Dallas and western suburbs were flooded. Heavy rainfall for the six-hour period ending at 2 p.m. EDT, included more than 1{ inches at Palacios, Texas. Almost 1 inch fell at College Station, Lufkin and Houston in Texas, and at Fort Polk, La. The nation's low for early Saturday was 20 degrees at Concord, N.H.

DOC.HEAD: City, County Clash Over Handling Of Mapplethorpe Charges
DOC.TEXT: With public sentiment now behind an art gallery exhibiting controversial photographs, city and county prosecutors are arguing over who should handle obscenity charges against its director. And city council members are suggesting the widely publicized case involving a collection of photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe is a losing cause. Sentiment against a city prosecution appeared to grow following the release of a poll Friday indicating strong public support for the gallery. Fifty-nine percent of those who responded to a poll conducted for The Cincinnati Post said they believe the photographs should be displayed. Councilman David Mann said the poll ``confirms my belief that a conviction is virtually impossible.'' The city's solicitor and Hamilton County prosecutor Arthur Ney plan to meet again Monday to resolve the dispute over prosecution of the Contemporary Arts Center and Director Dennis Barrie, who is to be arraigned Monday. A county grand jury indicted the gallery and Barrie last Saturday on two misdemeanor counts each of pandering obscenity and use of a minor in nudity-oriented matter for seven photos in the 175-picture exhibit. Two of the photos show nude children, and five depict homosexual acts. Prosecutors will have to convince a jury that the photos violate community standards in order to get an obscenity conviction. Several council members have called for the city to consider dropping the charges if it ends up with the case. ``We can't dictate to the city solicitor whether or not to proceed with the case, but we can certainly make our views known,'' said another councilman, Peter Strauss. ``I personally think they are going to have a hard time making a case that the show in its entirety lacks artistic value.'' Ney turned the prosecution over to the city Thursday, citing state law that requires cities to prosecute misdemeanors committed within their boundaries. However, the law permits a city and a county prosecutor to enter into an agreement to have the county prosecute the city's misdemeanor offenses. Ney and City Solicitor Richard Castellini met Friday but failed to reach agreement on which will handle the Mapplethorpe case. They plan to meet again Monday morning, when Barrie is arraigned in Hamilton County Municipal Court. Barrie has said he will plead innocent. Mayor Charles Luken said he thinks Ney gave the case to the city because he doubted he could win. ``I think this is a politically hot potato, and the reason Mr. Ney is doing this is that he doesn't feel he can win,'' Luken said. The county prosecutor's office rejected the suggestion, saying Ney handed the case off solely because he felt he was required to do so under state law.

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem's Mayor Condemns Jewish Settlers
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Teddy Kollek on Saturday denounced as ``extremists'' a group of Jewish nationalists who moved into the city's Christian sector and prompted a protest, his spokeswoman said. She said the mayor also told five visiting U.S. senators he fears the furor over the new settlement will dissuade Soviet immigrants from moving to the city. Kollek, who is Jewish, criticized Wednesday's move of about 150 Jewish nationalists into the building complex in the Christian section of the walled Old City, municipal spokeswoman Bonnie Boxer said. She quoted him as characterizing the settlers as ``extremists who concentrate only on themselves and their religious fervor.'' ``Once again, Jerusalem will be portrayed as a violent city and this will harm tourism, scare away potential investors and dissuade Soviet immigrants from choosing Jerusalem as their home,'' she also quoted him as saying. On Saturday, about 50 Christian and Moslem Palestinians demonstrated outside the 72-room complex settled by the Jews. On Thursday, Israeli police fired tear gas to disperse Christian clergymen and stone-throwing Palestinians protesting the settlement, while foreign tourists visiting for Easter week tried to steer clear of the violence. In Amman, Jordan, King Hussein on Saturday said in a written statement to The Associated Press that the Israeli police action against the Greek Orthodox patriarch and other protesting clerics in Jerusalem was a ``vicious and inhuman crime.'' The patriarch, Diodoros, was overcome by tear gas during the protest. Also Saturday, the U.S. senators, lead by Republican Robert Dole of Kansas, voiced their concern over the events surrounding the Jewish settlement, including the use of tear gas to break up the protest. The others in the Senate delegation were James McClure, R-Idaho; Alan Simpson, R-Wyo.; Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska; and Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. The senators also met Saturday with a group of Palestinian leaders from the occupied terrritories. The Palestinians urged the senators to help pressure Israel to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Jerusalem's Old City is divided into jealously guarded ethnic quarters that are home to 50,000 Moslems, about 7,000 Christians and 4,000 Jews. The old, walled city was controlled by Jordan from 1948 until 1967, when it was captured and annexed by Israel. The Jerusalem Magistrate's Court ruled Thursday that the property settled by the Jews actually belongs to the Greek Orthodox Church and ordered the Jewish families to move out. But the decision is under appeal, and police said they would let the settlers remain for the moment. The ultra-orthodox Jews say they bought the building from a Christian, but the Greek Orthodox Church said the complex was sold illegally. In the occupied the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities died overnight of beating injuries suffered earlier in the week, hospital officials said. His death brought to 207 the number of Palestinians killed by their Arab brethren most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. At least 673 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the 28-month-old uprising in the occupied lands. Forty-three Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Washington-British Columbia Border Back to Normal After Quake
DOC.TEXT: Traffic at border crossings returned to normal Saturday after a moderately strong earthquake shifted the walls of a Canada Customs office, shutting it down temporarily, authorities said. U.S. Customs Inspector John Nolte said the crossing between Blaine and Douglas, British Columbia was closed to northbound trucks after the quake, which registered 5.1 on the Richter scale at 10:33 p.m. PDT Friday. The quake was followed by about a dozen aftershocks, the strongest registering 4.1 on the Richter scale, said scientists at the University of Washington geophysics center. Unloaded trucks were diverted to the Peace Arch crossing and loaded trucks to the crossing between Sumas and Huntington, British Columbia, about 20 miles to the east. A few trucks were allowed to pass after about 9 a.m., and traffic was back to normal by noon without major delays or backups, Nolte said. Geophysicist Steve Malone said the quake occurred about three miles underground and three miles northeast of Deming, a town about 10 miles east of Bellingham. Walls at the Canada Customs office in Surrey, south of Vancouver, were moved ``about a quarter of an inch,'' said superintendent Glenn Bonnett. The building was closed overnight but was reopened after a structural inspection and operations appeared to be normal by midday, said U.S. Customs agent Randy Reed. Earthquake monitors at the university said there were reports of minor damage in three Washington counties, including broken glass and items jolted from shelves. A canopy at the Blaine border-crossing also was cracked, they said. County officials said callers who said they felt the quake reported no damage was reported other than pictures falling off a wall. Linda Twitchell, a Bellingham Herald copy editor, said she was in her recreation room when the quake hit and wondered briefly whether it would ruin the new addition to her home. ``It actually looked like the walls were moving in different directions,'' she said. ``I couldn't believe it,'' said Wally Beketa of nearby Custer. ``The bed shook. The mirrors danced on the walls.'' There were no reports of damage in British Columbia. The Richter scale measures ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake measuring 4 is capable of causing moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, and 6 can be severe.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Agency Says Americans Still Worry Over European Unity
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. International Trade Commission says American business still worries that greater unity among western Europeans will lead to a ``Fortress Europe'' designed to protect their businesses against American goods and services. It lists a long series of measures being taken by the 12 governments in the European Economic Community to bring freer trade with one another by 1992. The U.S. interests that could be hurt range from the sale of insurance to the showing of American television shows. In a thick report on developments in the community, also known as the Common Market, the commission recently made a point of American objections to European proposals for reciprocity: the idea that European firms should get the same treatment in America that American firms get in Europe. American firms prefer a different interpretation: that they get the same treatment in Europe as European firms give themselves. Of a proposal about mergers in the European insurance business, offered by France, the report said: ``Another reciprocity clause, albeit seemingly innocuous, will not assist in putting to rest the idea of `fortress Europe.''' President Bush's administration has been asking for more influence on the Europeans' decisions. As a result, leaders from the European Commission will come here April 23, headed by its chairman, Jacques Delors. It will be the first of a regular series of such meetings to take place twice a year. They will talk with Secretary of State James M. Baker III and other U.S. Cabinet members. Delors also will meet with Bush. The Europeans are expected to spend much of their visit, as other visitors have done, arguing that removal of barriers to trade among themselves poses no danger to American interests. The American commission, an independent body appointed by successive presidents, is less sure. ``Since the United States is outside the EC (European Community), measures that reduce internal barriers but leave external barriers unchanged cause trade diversion, that is, increased trade among EC member states at the expense of trade between the United States and the EC,'' it said. Its study is called ``The Effects of Greater Economic Integration Within the European Community on the United States: First Follow-Up Report.'' Dated for March, it was distributed to reporters this week. On the television issue, American pressure helped soften a European proposal to require that 60 percent of all broadcasts in the 12 countries originate in one of them. A European directive adopted last October asked some preferential treatment for programs originating in Europe. But it set no binding limits, leaving each of the member governments to set them if they choose. ``The U.S. government and the U.S. industry have continued to object to the local content provisions of the directive both on the grounds that they are protectionist and that they interfere with freedom of expression,'' the U.S. commission said. It also saw possible benefits to U.S. business from greater unity in Western Europe. American industry that competes with European exports will benefit as European products go more to European countries rather than overseas, it said, and added that any measures to reduce European barriers against imports will lower the price of American goods to European buyers.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Bus Shootings Reported
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents Saturday investigated two more Greyhound bus shootings that caused no injuries, the company said, and an official of the striking workers' union denied any responsibility for the violence. A bullet ricocheted off a San Antonio-bound bus at a Dallas area freeway interchange just before midnight Friday; hours later, a gunshot struck a bus en route from Birmingham, Ala., to Nashville, Tenn., said Greyhound spokesman Kevin Fry. Greyhound condemned the latest violence, which now totals more than 32 shooting attacks. The company says it won't negotiate with striking drivers and other employees until a week goes by without incident. ``We are hopeful we will get information to go on with these'' latest shootings, said Greyhound Lines Inc. spokesman George Gravley in Dallas. ``This is outrageous.'' The company's offer of a $100,000 reward for information leading to arrests in violence against buses and their occupants applies to the latest shootings, said Gravley. An Amalgamated Transit Union representative in Dallas denied that strikers were responsible for the latest violence and said he had doubts about the Texas report. ``The word I got was it was just a little indentation'' on the side of the San Antonio-bound bus, said ATU representative Donald Hardin. ``I have very serious doubts about that one. If it was a bullet, it wasn't from any of our guys. We have been very peaceful here.'' The Texas bus had no passengers aboard at the time of the shooting, said Fry. The bullet struck the bus about 5 feet, 10 inches off the ground, near an American flag painted on its right side. The bus, which continued on to San Antonio after the driver discovered the damage, was met by police and U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents. The investigators ``determined it was a small- to mid-caliber bullet fired from a handgun, fired from behind the bus and it ricocheted off the bus, never penetrating the skin,'' Fry said. The second shooting occurred on a Nashville-bound bus with six passengers aboard, said Fry. Its driver was at an undetermined location on Interstate 65 when gunfire hit the eastbound bus about 3:20 a.m. Investigators from the FBI and ATF were looking into the shooting along with state and local authorities, said Fry. Both agencies di not immediately return calls from The AP. On March 2, Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers walked out in an argument over wages and job security. The company has been operating a reduced schedule since, using permanent replacements and drivers willing to cross picket lines. Greyhound, besides the shooting attacks on buses, has reported 70 bomb threats and more than 100 other incidents of violence. The unions have also reported violence directed at them. A picketing driver, 59-year-old Robert Waterhouse, died when he was crushed by a bus driven by a replacement driver in Redding, Calif. No charges were filed in that case.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Ushers In Christianity's Holiest Day
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II ushered in Christianity's holiest day in the light of small candles held by thousands of faithful at Easter vigil services Saturday night in St. Peter's Basilica. Preceded by cardinals and bishops in a slow procession toward the altar, the pope carried before him a long white candle he lit to open the service commemorating the night Jesus Christ rose from the dead after his crucifixion. In other Easter observances, peace activists from both Germanys protested together for the first time during traditional holiday marches Saturday. The German custom of Easter marches for peace dates back to the 1950s, but protests were held separately in East and West Germany for decades until the border opened during East Germany's popular revolution last fall. The cavernous St. Peter's Basilica, the largest church in Christendom, was dark and silent late Saturday as the procession moved toward the altar under the ``Baldacchino,'' the Baroque canopy designed by 17th century sculptor Gian Lorenzo Bernini. After the third chanting of the ``Lumen Christi'' (Light of Christ), the the congregation began lighting candles to symbolize the ``pilgrimage from darkness to light.'' Earlier Saturday, the Polish-born pope met with an aide to Mikhail S. Gorbachev one day after the Soviet president threatened to impose an economic blockade on the rebellious Baltic republic of Lithuania. A Vatican spokesman, Monsignor Piero Pennacchini, said the 30-minute private audience was requested by Vadim Zagladin, a special adviser to Gorbachev. But the spokesmen did not say whether it touched on the crisis in Lithuania, which declared independence from Moscow on March 11. Casimir Lozoraitis, an official of the Lithuanian mission to the Holy See, said he had been informed by ``informal contacts'' that the pontiff's meeting included a discussion of Lithuania, but there were no details. The pope also sent an Easter message to Lithuania, which is 80 percent Roman Catholic. ``In this hour of trepidation and hope, I am particularly near to the Lithuanian church,'' the pope said in Latin in the telegram sent to Cardinal Vincentas Skadkevicius of Lithuania. An Italian text of the telegram was provided by the Vatican. During the Easter vigil, the pope baptized 19 people from 11 countries. After a Mass lasting into the early morning hours Sunday, the pope had little time to rest before Easter morning, which he will celebrate with an open-air Mass in St. Peter's Square. At noon, he will give his ``Urbi et Orbi'' (to the city of Rome and the world) message from the balcony overlooking the square.

DOC.HEAD: Fast-Food Restaurant's Customers Urged To Get Shots
DOC.TEXT: Customers of a McDonald's restaurant that serves an estimated 1,200 people a day have been urged to get shots if they ate there during the working hours of a teen-age cook diagnosed with hepatitis. Only co-workers and the restaurant's patrons during the worker's three shifts between March 31 and April 7 were advised to get the gamma globulin shot, said Dr. James Howell of the state health department. Health officials don't know how many people were exposed to hepatitis A, which is spread by poor personal hygiene, poor sanitation and intimate contact. Its symptoms include fever, nausea, abdominal pain, dark urine and jaundice. The employee, who cooks fries, is on sick leave and will return to work when he is healthy, Howell said. His name wasn't released. In 1988, 28,000 hepatitis cases across the country were reported to the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. In 1989, cases increased 30 percent to about 36,000. CDC officials say they can't explain the increase.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Steel Tubes Reportedly Connected With Satellite Launcher
DOC.TEXT: The steel tube sections seized en route to Iraq and suspected by Customs officials to be parts of a huge gun could be connected with a space satellite launch system, government sources were quoted as saying Saturday. Press Association, the British domestic news agency, quoted unidentified ``reliable government sources'' as saying they had correspondence linking British industry with the Brussels company Space Research Projects, described as dealing in international arms sales. The correspondence refers to orders for the manufacture of smoothbore pipes that experts believe match the specification detailed in the Belgian company's design for a space satellite launch system, the sources were quoted as saying. It was not clear from the report whether the link consisted of more than a match in specifications. The report did not name the British manufacturer allegedly involved. In December, Iraq surprised other nations by launching a rocket it said could be used to put a satellite into space. Press Association said the British sources made known the correspondence to explain the interest of the Customs and Excise department in the steel tubes being held for investigation at Middlesbrough on the northeast coast of England. Engineering experts stressed that the orders could be placed in such a way that the manufacturers would believe they were providing pipe work for the petroleum industry. Press Association did not name the government department of the sources, but The Sunday Telegraph, The Sunday Times, and the Observer all carried articles quoting Customs sources on the same subject. The consignment being held at Middlesbrough was to have been loaded on a ship bound for Iraq when Customs officers seized it Tuesday. In the days since, Iraq has claimed the metal tubes were pipes for a petrochemical plant. The British manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters, said their work was not intended for armaments and was known to the government. Customs, however, said the eight pieces of steel tube could unquestionably be used as a huge gun barrel. Arms experts have given conflicting opinions about whether the steel sections could be used as a weapon. The Belgian company mentioned in the Press Association report, Space Research, was owned by Dr. Gerald Bull, an American ballistics expert. Bull, 62, a Canadian-born American citizen, was slain March 22. Belgian police said he was shot twice in the head. They said the gunman used a silencer and the motive was not robbery because $20,000 was found in the victim's pockets. Jane's Defense Weekly said Bull had been a principal designer of South Africa's G5 howitzers, which have been sold to Iraq. Britain banned all arms sales to Iraq and its enemy Iran following the outbreak of the 8-year-old Persian Gulf War. There has been a cease-fire since August 1988, but Iran and Iraq are still not officially at peace and the British embargo remains.

DOC.HEAD: Water, Water Nowhere But in the Middle of the Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The agency's ...,' to CORRECT to federal government sted courts; SUBS 16th graf, `Los Angeles ...,' to DELETE reference to Sierra Nevada.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA2, PMS1
DOC.TEXT: Worries about California's fourth straight year of drought seem far away on the lush oasislike fairways of the Coachella Valley, billed as the golf capital of the world.
